Is it possible to style a dialog ?

Yes, it is possible to style a dialog in Android. You can customize the appearance of a dialog by creating a custom style and applying it to the dialog. Here's an example of how you can style a dialog:
1. Create a new style resource file in your `res/values/styles.xml` file. For example:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <resources> <!-- Base application theme --> <style name="AppTheme" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.NoActionBar"> <!-- Customize your theme here --> </style>
<!-- Custom dialog style --> <style name="CustomDialogStyle" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.Dialog"> <item name="colorPrimary">@color/colorPrimary</item> <item name="colorPrimaryDark">@color/colorPrimaryDark</item> <item name="colorAccent">@color/colorAccent</item> <item name="android:textColor">@android:color/white</item> <item name="android:background">@color/colorPrimaryDark</item> </style> </resources> ```
In this example, we've created a new style called `CustomDialogStyle` that inherits from the `Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.Dialog` theme. We've customized the primary, primary dark, and accent colors, as well as the text color and background color.
2. Apply the custom style to your dialog when creating it. For example:
```kotlin val dialog = AlertDialog.Builder(this, R.style.CustomDialogStyle) .setTitle("Dialog Title") .setMessage("This is a styled dialog.") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> } .create() dialog.show() ```
In this example, we're passing `R.style.CustomDialogStyle` as the second parameter to the `AlertDialog.Builder` constructor, which applies the custom style to the dialog.
You can customize various aspects of the dialog by modifying the style attributes in your `styles.xml` file. Here are some common attributes you can customize:
- `android:textColor`: Sets the text color for the dialog title and message. - `android:background`: Sets the background color or drawable for the dialog. - `android:windowBackground`: Sets the background color or drawable for the dialog window. - `android:windowTitleStyle`: Customizes the style of the dialog title. - `android:windowTitleBackgroundStyle`: Customizes the background of the dialog title. - `android:buttonBarPositiveButtonStyle`: Customizes the style of the positive button. - `android:buttonBarNegativeButtonStyle`: Customizes the style of the negative button.
You can also create custom layouts for your dialog by inflating a custom layout in the `AlertDialog.Builder` or by extending the `DialogFragment` class and providing your own layout.
By styling your dialogs, you can make them visually consistent with the rest of your app's design and provide a better user experience.
Create custom dialog to show Device information

Sure, here's an example of how you can create a custom dialog to show device information in Android:
1. First, create a new layout file for your custom dialog, e.g., `dialog_device_info.xml`:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:orientation="vertical" android:padding="16dp">
<TextView android:id="@+id/tvDeviceInfo" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:textAppearance="?attr/textAppearanceBody1" android:textIsSelectable="true" />
</LinearLayout> ```
This layout contains a `TextView` where we'll display the device information.
2. Next, create a custom dialog class that extends `DialogFragment`:
```kotlin class DeviceInfoDialog : DialogFragment() {
override fun onCreateDialog(savedInstanceState: Bundle?): Dialog { val builder = AlertDialog.Builder(requireActivity()) val inflater = requireActivity().layoutInflater val view = inflater.inflate(R.layout.dialog_device_info, null)
val tvDeviceInfo = view.findViewById<TextView>(R.id.tvDeviceInfo) val deviceInfo = getDeviceInfo() tvDeviceInfo.text = deviceInfo
builder.setView(view) .setTitle("Device Information") .setPositiveButton("OK") { _, _ -> dismiss() }
return builder.create() }
private fun getDeviceInfo(): String { val manufacturer = Build.MANUFACTURER val brand = Build.BRAND val model = Build.MODEL val device = Build.DEVICE val version = Build.VERSION.RELEASE val sdkVersion = Build.VERSION.SDK_INT
return "Manufacturer: $manufacturer\n" + "Brand: $brand\n" + "Model: $model\n" + "Device: $device\n" + "Android Version: $version\n" + "SDK Version: $sdkVersion" } } ```
In this class:
- We override the `onCreateDialog` method to create and return our custom dialog. - We inflate the `dialog_device_info.xml` layout and find the `TextView` to display the device information. - We call the `getDeviceInfo` function to retrieve the device information as a string. - We set the device information text to the `TextView`. - We configure the dialog builder with the custom view, title, and an "OK" button to dismiss the dialog.
3. To show the custom dialog, you can create an instance of the `DeviceInfoDialog` class and call `show` on it:
```kotlin class YourActivity : AppCompatActivity() { override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { super.onCreate(savedInstanceState) setContentView(R.layout.your_layout)
// Show the device info dialog val deviceInfoDialog = DeviceInfoDialog() deviceInfoDialog.show(supportFragmentManager, "DeviceInfoDialog") } } ```
In this example, we create an instance of the `DeviceInfoDialog` class and call `show` on it, passing the `supportFragmentManager` and a tag for the dialog.
When you run your app and reach the point where you show the dialog, you should see a custom dialog with the device information displayed in the `TextView`.
You can further customize the dialog by modifying the layout file (`dialog_device_info.xml`) or the dialog styles in your `styles.xml` file.
how to show a different imageview based on data from pos_order room table?

To show a different `ImageView` based on data from the `pos_order` room table, you can follow these steps:
1. **Define the images and their corresponding conditions**
First, you need to determine the conditions or values from the `pos_order` table that will determine which image should be displayed. For example, let's assume you want to show different images based on the `order_status` column.
2. **Create a function to map the conditions to the corresponding image resources**
Create a function that takes the relevant data from the `pos_order` table (e.g., `order_status`) and returns the appropriate image resource ID. Here's an example:
```kotlin fun getImageResourceForOrderStatus(orderStatus: String): Int { return when (orderStatus) { "NEW" -> R.drawable.ic_new_order "STARTED" -> R.drawable.ic_order_started "FINISHED" -> R.drawable.ic_order_finished else -> R.drawable.ic_unknown_status } } ```
In this example, the `getImageResourceForOrderStatus` function takes the `order_status` value and returns the corresponding image resource ID based on the conditions.
3. **Bind the `ImageView` to the data from the `pos_order` table**
In your adapter or view holder class, bind the `ImageView` to the data from the `pos_order` table using the function you created in step 2.
For example, if you're using a `RecyclerView` with a `ListAdapter`, you can update the `onBindViewHolder` method like this:
```kotlin override fun onBindViewHolder(holder: ViewHolder, position: Int) { val order = getItem(position) val orderStatus = order.orderStatus
holder.bind(order) holder.orderStatusImageView.setImageResource(getImageResourceForOrderStatus(orderStatus)) } ```
In this example, we're calling the `getImageResourceForOrderStatus` function with the `order_status` value from the `pos_order` table and setting the resulting image resource to the `orderStatusImageView`.
4. **Update the view holder to include the `ImageView`**
Make sure your view holder class has a reference to the `ImageView` where you want to display the order status image. For example:
```kotlin class ViewHolder(itemView: View) : RecyclerView.ViewHolder(itemView) { val orderStatusImageView: ImageView = itemView.findViewById(R.id.orderStatusImageView) // Other view references...
fun bind(order: Order) { // Bind other views... } } ```
In this example, the `ViewHolder` class has an `orderStatusImageView` property that references the `ImageView` in the item layout.
By following these steps, you should be able to show different `ImageView` resources based on the data from the `pos_order` room table. You can modify the conditions and image resources in the `getImageResourceForOrderStatus` function to suit your specific requirements.
how can i set the background colour of a constraint layout?

You can set the background color of a `ConstraintLayout` in several ways:
1. **Using XML**
In your layout XML file, you can set the `android:background` attribute of the `ConstraintLayout` to a color value or a drawable resource.
For example, to set a solid color background:
```xml <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:background="#FF0000"> <!-- Set background color to red -->
<!-- Your layout content -->
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
Or, to set a drawable background:
```xml <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:background="@drawable/background_drawable"> <!-- Set background to a drawable resource -->
<!-- Your layout content -->
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
2. **Using Code**
You can also set the background color of a `ConstraintLayout` programmatically in your activity or fragment code.
```kotlin val constraintLayout = findViewById<ConstraintLayout>(R.id.constraintLayout) constraintLayout.setBackgroundColor(Color.RED) // Set background color to red ```
Or, to set a drawable background:
```kotlin val constraintLayout = findViewById<ConstraintLayout>(R.id.constraintLayout) val drawable = ContextCompat.getDrawable(this, R.drawable.background_drawable) constraintLayout.background = drawable ```
3. **Using Styles**
You can define a style in your `styles.xml` file and apply it to the `ConstraintLayout`.
In `styles.xml`:
```xml <style name="CustomConstraintLayoutStyle"> <item name="android:background">@color/your_color</item> <!-- Other style attributes --> </style> ```
In your layout XML:
```xml <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" style="@style/CustomConstraintLayoutStyle">
<!-- Your layout content -->
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
4. **Using Themes**
You can also set the background color of a `ConstraintLayout` by defining a theme in your `styles.xml` file and applying it to your app or activity.
In `styles.xml`:
```xml <style name="AppTheme" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.NoActionBar"> <item name="android:windowBackground">@color/your_color</item> <!-- Other theme attributes --> </style> ```
In your `AndroidManifest.xml`:
```xml <application android:theme="@style/AppTheme"> <!-- Your app components --> </application> ```
By using any of these methods, you can set the background color of a `ConstraintLayout` to a solid color or a drawable resource. Choose the method that best suits your use case and coding style.
can you explain backgroundTintMode?

Sure, `backgroundTintMode` is an attribute in Android that allows you to specify how the background tint should be applied to a view. It works in conjunction with the `backgroundTint` attribute, which sets the tint color or drawable for the view's background.
The `backgroundTintMode` attribute can take one of the following values:
1. **`src_over`**: This is the default value. It applies the tint color or drawable on top of the view's background, allowing the original background to show through.
2. **`src_in`**: This mode applies the tint color or drawable only to the areas of the view's background that are opaque. Transparent areas of the background are left untinted.
3. **`src_atop`**: This mode applies the tint color or drawable on top of the view's background, but only where the background is opaque. Transparent areas of the background are left untinted.
4. **`multiply`**: This mode multiplies the tint color or drawable with the view's background color, resulting in a darker color.
5. **`screen`**: This mode multiplies the inverse of the tint color or drawable with the inverse of the view's background color, resulting in a lighter color.
6. **`add`**: This mode adds the tint color or drawable to the view's background color, clamping the result to the valid color range.
Here's an example of how you can set the `backgroundTintMode` in your XML layout:
```xml <Button android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:backgroundTint="@color/tint_color" android:backgroundTintMode="multiply" android:text="Button" /> ```
In this example, the `backgroundTint` attribute sets the tint color for the button's background, and the `backgroundTintMode` attribute is set to `multiply`, which will multiply the tint color with the button's background color, resulting in a darker color.
You can also set the `backgroundTintMode` programmatically in your Java or Kotlin code:
```kotlin val button = findViewById<Button>(R.id.button) button.backgroundTintMode = PorterDuff.Mode.MULTIPLY ```
The `backgroundTintMode` attribute is particularly useful when you want to apply a tint to a view's background in a specific way, such as overlaying a color on top of an image or adjusting the opacity of the background.
It's important to note that the `backgroundTintMode` attribute only affects the tint applied to the background and not the background itself. If you want to change the background directly, you should use the `background` attribute or set the background programmatically.
changing backgroundTint causes background to become semi transparent

If changing the `backgroundTint` attribute causes the background to become semi-transparent, it's likely due to the way the tint is being applied to the view's background. This behavior can occur when the view's background is a drawable resource, such as an image or a shape drawable.
When you set the `backgroundTint` attribute, Android applies the tint color or drawable on top of the view's existing background. If the tint color has an alpha value (transparency), it can cause the underlying background to appear semi-transparent.
To resolve this issue, you have a few options:
1. **Use a solid color for the tint**
If you want a solid background color, set the `backgroundTint` attribute to a solid color without any transparency. For example:
```xml <View android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="100dp" android:backgroundTint="#FF0000" /> <!-- Solid red color --> ```
2. **Set the `backgroundTintMode` to `src_in`**
The `src_in` mode applies the tint color or drawable only to the opaque areas of the view's background, leaving the transparent areas untinted. This can help preserve the original background's transparency.
```xml <View android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="100dp" android:background="@drawable/your_background" android:backgroundTint="#80FF0000" <!-- Semi-transparent red color --> android:backgroundTintMode="src_in" /> ```
3. **Set the background directly**
Instead of using `backgroundTint`, you can set the background directly using the `background` attribute or programmatically. This way, you have full control over the background color or drawable without any tinting applied.
```xml <View android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="100dp" android:background="#FF0000" /> <!-- Solid red color --> ```
4. **Use a separate view for the tint**
If you want to apply a tint on top of a background drawable while preserving its transparency, you can use a separate view for the tint. For example, you can use a `FrameLayout` with a `View` for the background and another `View` for the tint on top.
```xml <FrameLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="100dp">
<View android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:background="@drawable/your_background" />
<View android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:background="#80FF0000" /> <!-- Semi-transparent red tint -->
</FrameLayout> ```
By using one of these approaches, you can apply a tint color or drawable to a view's background without causing unintended transparency issues.
setting a cardBackgroundColor displays a semi transparent colour not the one i'm setting it to

If you're setting the `cardBackgroundColor` attribute on a `CardView` and it's displaying a semi-transparent color instead of the solid color you specified, it's likely due to the way the `CardView` handles the background color.
By default, the `CardView` applies a semi-transparent overlay on top of the background color to create the card effect. This overlay is controlled by the `cardElevation` attribute, which determines the shadow and elevation of the card.
To resolve this issue and display the solid color you've set for `cardBackgroundColor`, you need to disable the elevation effect by setting `cardElevation` to `0dp`. This will remove the semi-transparent overlay and display the solid background color you've specified.
Here's an example:
```xml <androidx.cardview.widget.CardView android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:cardBackgroundColor="#FF0000" <!-- Set the desired solid color --> app:cardElevation="0dp" <!-- Disable the elevation effect --> app:cardCornerRadius="8dp"> <!-- Optional: Set the corner radius -->
<!-- Your card content goes here -->
</androidx.cardview.widget.CardView> ```
In this example, we've set the `cardBackgroundColor` to a solid red color (`#FF0000`), and we've set the `cardElevation` to `0dp` to disable the elevation effect and remove the semi-transparent overlay.
Additionally, you can adjust the `cardCornerRadius` attribute to change the rounded corners of the `CardView`.
If you want to keep the elevation effect but still display a solid background color, you can set the `cardBackgroundColor` to a solid color and adjust the `cardElevation` value to your desired elevation level. However, keep in mind that the elevation effect will still apply a semi-transparent overlay on top of the background color.
By disabling the elevation effect (`cardElevation="0dp"`), you can ensure that the `cardBackgroundColor` you set is displayed as a solid color without any semi-transparent overlay.

That works better but now displays the wrong color. This seems to be only when i set the color programatically

If the color displayed is incorrect when you set it programmatically, it could be due to a few reasons:
1. **Color Resource Mismatch**
Ensure that the color resource you're using in your code matches the color resource you're expecting. Double-check the resource name and the actual color value defined in your `colors.xml` file.
2. **Color Format Mismatch**
Make sure that the color format you're using in your code matches the format expected by the `setBackgroundColor` method. The `setBackgroundColor` method expects an `int` value representing the color in the format `0xAARRGGBB` (where AA is the alpha value, and RR, GG, BB are the red, green, and blue values, respectively).
If you're using a hexadecimal color value (e.g., `#FF0000`), you need to convert it to an `int` value first. You can use the `Color.parseColor` method or the `0xAARRGGBB` format directly.
Here's an example of how to set the background color programmatically using the `0xAARRGGBB` format:
```kotlin val color = 0xFFFF0000 // Solid red color binding.buttonLayout.setBackgroundColor(color) ```
3. **Data Binding Issue**
If you're using data binding and setting the color through a variable, ensure that the variable is being updated correctly and that the binding is working as expected.
You can try setting a breakpoint or adding logging statements to verify the value of the variable before it's being used to set the background color.
4. **View Hierarchy Issue**
Double-check that you're setting the background color on the correct view. If you have nested views or complex view hierarchies, make sure you're targeting the intended view.
5. **Theme or Style Overrides**
Ensure that your app's theme or styles are not overriding the background color you're setting programmatically. Check your `styles.xml` file and the theme applied to your activity or fragment.
If none of these suggestions resolve the issue, you can try setting the background color in the XML layout file instead of programmatically. This can help you isolate whether the issue is related to your code or the data binding setup.
Additionally, you can share the relevant code snippets, including the data binding setup and the code where you're setting the background color programmatically, to help us better understand and diagnose the issue.

The issue you're facing is likely due to the way you're returning the color resource IDs from the `getColourResourceForOrderStatus` function.
When you return `R.color.white`, `R.color.elis_green`, `R.color.elis_red`, or `R.color.elis_send_green`, you're returning the resource ID of the color, not the actual color value.
To get the correct color value, you need to use the `ContextCompat.getColor` method, which resolves the color resource ID to the actual color value based on the current theme and context.
Here's how you can modify the `getColourResourceForOrderStatus` function:
```kotlin private fun getColourResourceForOrderStatus(orderStatus: String?, context: Context): Int { return when (orderStatus) { Constants.APP_STATUS_NEW.toString() -> ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.color.white) Constants.APP_STATUS_STARTED.toString() -> ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.color.elis_green) Constants.APP_STATUS_FINISHED.toString() -> ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.color.elis_red) Constants.APP_STATUS_SENT.toString() -> ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.color.elis_send_green) else -> ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.color.elis_send_green) } } ```
In this modified function, we're passing the `Context` as a parameter, and then using `ContextCompat.getColor(context, colorResourceId)` to get the actual color value from the resource ID.
Now, in your `OrdersAdapter` or `OrdersViewHolder`, you'll need to pass the `Context` to the `getColourResourceForOrderStatus` function when setting the background color.

```kotlin class OrdersViewHolder(private var binding: OrderCardviewBinding) : RecyclerView.ViewHolder(binding.root) { fun bind(clickListener: MyClickListener, orders: Order) { val orderStatus = orders.appOrderStatus binding.order = orders binding.deliveryDate = getOrderDate(orders.deliveryDate) binding.clickListener = clickListener binding.buttonColour = getColourResourceForOrderStatus(orderStatus, binding.root.context)
binding.executePendingBindings() }
// ... } ```
In this example, we're passing `binding.root.context` as the `Context` parameter to the `getColourResourceForOrderStatus` function.
By using `ContextCompat.getColor`, you should now see the correct colors being displayed in your RecyclerView based on the order status.

does app:tint accept a hex color?

Yes, the `app:tint` attribute in Android can accept a hexadecimal color value.
You can set the `app:tint` attribute to a hexadecimal color value in your XML layout file like this:
```xml <ImageView android:id="@+id/myImageView" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:tint="#FF0000" /> <!-- Set tint to red color --> ```
In this example, the `app:tint` attribute is set to `#FF0000`, which is the hexadecimal value for the red color.
You can use any valid hexadecimal color value with the `app:tint` attribute. The format can be either:
- `#RRGGBB` (e.g., `#FF0000` for red) - `#AARRGGBB` (e.g., `#88FF0000` for semi-transparent red)
Where:
- `RR` represents the red value (00 to FF) - `GG` represents the green value (00 to FF) - `BB` represents the blue value (00 to FF) - `AA` (optional) represents the alpha value or transparency (00 to FF, where 00 is fully transparent and FF is fully opaque)
You can also use the `@color` resource reference with the `app:tint` attribute if you have defined the color in your `colors.xml` file:
```xml <ImageView android:id="@+id/myImageView" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:tint="@color/my_custom_color" /> ```
In this case, `@color/my_custom_color` refers to a color resource defined in your `colors.xml` file.
Additionally, you can set the `app:tint` attribute programmatically using the `setColorFilter` method:
```kotlin val imageView = findViewById<ImageView>(R.id.myImageView) imageView.setColorFilter(Color.parseColor("#FF0000"), PorterDuff.Mode.SRC_IN) ```
In this example, we're using the `Color.parseColor` method to parse the hexadecimal color value `#FF0000` and then applying it as a color filter to the `ImageView` using the `setColorFilter` method.
So, in summary, the `app:tint` attribute in Android does accept hexadecimal color values, allowing you to set the tint color for views like `ImageView`, `Button`, or any other tintable views.

How to disable a click on a cardview?

To disable a click on a `CardView`, you can set the `clickable` and `focusable` attributes to `false` in your XML layout file. This will prevent the `CardView` from receiving click events and becoming focused.
Here's an example of how you can modify your `CardView` in the XML layout:
```xml <androidx.cardview.widget.CardView android:id="@+id/myCardView" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:clickable="false" android:focusable="false" app:cardCornerRadius="8dp" app:cardElevation="4dp">
<!-- Your CardView content goes here -->
</androidx.cardview.widget.CardView> ```
In this example, we've set `android:clickable="false"` and `android:focusable="false"` on the `CardView`. This will prevent the `CardView` from receiving click events and becoming focused.
If you're using a `RecyclerView` with a `CardView` as the item view, you can also disable the click event in your adapter's `onBindViewHolder` method by setting the `clickable` and `focusable` attributes programmatically:
```kotlin class MyAdapter(private val data: List<DataItem>) : RecyclerView.Adapter<MyAdapter.ViewHolder>() {
override fun onBindViewHolder(holder: ViewHolder, position: Int) { val item = data[position] holder.bind(item)
// Disable click on the CardView holder.cardView.isClickable = false holder.cardView.isFocusable = false }
inner class ViewHolder(itemView: View) : RecyclerView.ViewHolder(itemView) { val cardView: CardView = itemView.findViewById(R.id.myCardView)
fun bind(item: DataItem) { // Bind your data to the views } } } ```
In this example, we're setting `isClickable` and `isFocusable` to `false` on the `CardView` inside the `onBindViewHolder` method of the adapter.
By disabling the `clickable` and `focusable` attributes, you'll prevent the `CardView` from receiving click events and becoming focused. This can be useful when you want to display the `CardView` as a non-interactive element or when you want to handle click events differently (e.g., on a specific child view within the `CardView`).
Note that if you have any click listeners or touch event handlers set up on the `CardView` or its child views, you may need to remove or disable them as well to fully prevent any click or touch interactions.

To total the records in the `pos_order` table based on the `point_of_service_no` and display this total in the `pos_cardview.xml` layout, you can follow these steps:

// ... } ```
2. In your `PosViewModel` (or wherever you're managing the data for the `PosFragment`), retrieve the total count of orders for each `PointsOfService` object:
```kotlin class PosViewModel(application: Application) : AndroidViewModel(application) { private val database = OrderInfoDatabase.getInstance(application)
val pointsOfService: LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>> = database.orderInfoDao .getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders() .asLiveData()
// ... } ```
Here, we're assuming you have a `PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders` class that combines the `PointsOfService` data with the total order count:
```kotlin data class PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( @Embedded val pointsOfService: PointsOfService, @Relation( parentColumn = "pointOfServiceNo", entityColumn = "point_of_service_no" ) val orders: List<Order> = emptyList(), val totalOrders: Int ) ```
3. In your `PointOfServiceAdapter`, bind the total order count to the corresponding `TextView` in the `pos_cardview.xml` layout:
```kotlin class PointOfServiceAdapter(private val clickListener: MyClickListener) : RecyclerView.Adapter<PointOfServiceAdapter.PointsOfServiceViewHolder>() {
private var data: List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders> = emptyList()
override fun onBindViewHolder(holder: PointsOfServiceViewHolder, position: Int) { val pointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders = data[position] holder.bind(clickListener, pointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders) }
class PointsOfServiceViewHolder(private val binding: PosCardviewBinding) : RecyclerView.ViewHolder(binding.root) {
fun bind( clickListener: MyClickListener, pointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders: PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders ) { binding.pos = pointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders.pointsOfService binding.totalOrders = pointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders.totalOrders.toString() binding.clickListener = clickListener binding.executePendingBindings() } }
// ... } ```
4. In your `pos_cardview.xml` layout file, add a `TextView` to display the total order count:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools">

<!-- ... -->
<TextView android:id="@+id/totalOrdersTextView" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:text="@{@string/total_orders(totalOrders)}" android:textColor="@color/elis_black" android:textSize="16sp" app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" />
</com.google.android.material.card.MaterialCardView> </layout> ```
In this layout, we've added a `TextView` with the ID `totalOrdersTextView` and bound its `text` attribute to the `totalOrders` variable using a string resource. The `@string/total_orders(totalOrders)` syntax assumes you have a string resource named `total_orders` with a placeholder for the total order count.

```kotlin @Dao interface OrderInfoDao { // ...
@Transaction @Query(""" SELECT points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup """) fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String ): LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>>
// ... } ```
In this updated query, we're using a subquery to count the number of orders in the `pos_order` table for each `point_of_service_no`, `deliveryAddressNo`, and `orderingGroup` combination. The result of this subquery is aliased as `totalOrders`.
2. Create a new data class to hold the `PointsOfService` data along with the total order count:
```kotlin data class PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( @Embedded val pointsOfService: PointsOfService, val totalOrders: Int ) ```

How can i use totalPOS within @...\res\layout\fragment_pos.xml

To use the `totalPOS` value within the `fragment_pos.xml` layout file, you'll need to pass the value from your ViewModel to the Fragment and then bind it to the corresponding view in the layout file.
Here's how you can achieve this:
1. In your `PosViewModel`, create a `LiveData` property to hold the `totalPOS` value:
```kotlin class PosViewModel(application: Application) : AndroidViewModel(application) { private val database = OrderInfoDatabase.getInstance(application)
private val _totalPOS = MutableLiveData<Int>() val totalPOS: LiveData<Int> = _totalPOS
fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrdersAndTotalPOS( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String ) { val data = database.orderInfoDao.getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrdersAndTotalPOS( deliveryAddressNo, orderingGroup ).value
if (data != null) { _totalPOS.value = data.first().totalPOS } }
// ... } ```
In this example, we've added a `_totalPOS` private mutable `LiveData` property and a public `totalPOS` immutable `LiveData` property. The `getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrdersAndTotalPOS` function retrieves the data from the database and sets the `_totalPOS` value with the `totalPOS` value from the first item in the list.
2. In your `PosFragment`, observe the `totalPOS` `LiveData` and bind it to the corresponding view in the `fragment_pos.xml` layout file:
```kotlin class PosFragment : Fragment() { private lateinit var binding: FragmentPosBinding private val sharedViewModel: ParamsViewModel by activityViewModels() private val posViewModel: PosViewModel by viewModels { SharedViewModelFactory(sharedViewModel, requireActivity().application) }
override fun onCreateView( inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle? ): View { binding = FragmentPosBinding.inflate(inflater, container, false) binding.lifecycleOwner = viewLifecycleOwner binding.sharedViewModel = sharedViewModel binding.posViewModel = posViewModel
// Observe the totalPOS value and bind it to the corresponding view posViewModel.totalPOS.observe(viewLifecycleOwner) { totalPOS -> binding.totalPOS = totalPOS.toString() }
return binding.root }
// ... } ```
In this example, we're observing the `totalPOS` `LiveData` from the `PosViewModel` and binding its value to the `totalPOS` variable in the `FragmentPosBinding`.
3. In your `fragment_pos.xml` layout file, add a `TextView` or any other view to display the `totalPOS` value, and bind it to the `totalPOS` variable:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools">

<!-- Other views -->
</layout> ```
In this example, we've added a `TextView` with the ID `totalPOSTextView` and bound its `text` attribute to the `totalPOS` variable using a string resource. The `@string/total_pos(totalPOS)` syntax assumes you have a string resource named `total_pos` with a placeholder for the total `PointsOfService` count.
For example, in your `strings.xml` file:
```xml <string name="total_pos">Total POS: %s</string> ```
By following these steps, you'll be able to display the `totalPOS` value in the `fragment_pos.xml` layout file. Ensure that the `totalPOS` variable has the correct data type. If you're trying to bind it to a `TextView` or any other view that expects a string value, make sure that `totalPOS` is a string or can be converted to a string.

If you're using Data Binding, verify that the binding expression you're using to bind the `totalPOS` variable to the corresponding view is correct. Double-check the syntax and the variable name in the binding expression.

Make sure that you're referencing the correct `PosViewModel` instance in your `PosFragment.kt` file. If you're using the `by viewModels()` or `by activityViewModels()` delegates, ensure that the ViewModel factory and the ViewModel class are correctly configured.

AutosizeText set to uniform and maxlines set to 1 but not all text shows?

If you have set `android:autoSizeTextType="uniform"` and `android:maxLines="1"` on a `TextView`, but not all the text is showing, it could be due to the following reasons:
1. **Text length exceeds the available width**
When you set `android:autoSizeTextType="uniform"`, the `TextView` will automatically adjust the text size to fit the available width while maintaining a uniform text appearance. However, if the text length is too long and exceeds the available width, the text may be truncated or cut off.
2. **Insufficient space for the minimum text size**
The `autoSizeTextType="uniform"` attribute adjusts the text size based on the available width and the minimum and maximum text sizes specified. If the minimum text size is too large for the available width, the text may be truncated or cut off.
3. **Ellipsize attribute not set**
By default, when `android:maxLines="1"` is set, the `TextView` will truncate the text without any visual indication that the text has been cut off. To show an ellipsis (...) at the end of the truncated text, you need to set the `android:ellipsize` attribute.
Here's an example of how you can set the `ellipsize` attribute:
```xml <TextView android:id="@+id/myTextView" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:autoSizeTextType="uniform" android:ellipsize="end" android:maxLines="1" android:text="This is a long text that may be truncated" /> ```
In this example, `android:ellipsize="end"` will display an ellipsis (...) at the end of the truncated text.
You can also try adjusting the `android:minWidth` and `android:maxWidth` attributes to provide more or less space for the `TextView` to adjust the text size.
If you're still experiencing issues with the text being truncated or cut off, you may need to consider alternative approaches, such as:
- Using a `ScrollView` or a `HorizontalScrollView` to allow the text to wrap or scroll horizontally. - Splitting the text into multiple lines by removing the `android:maxLines="1"` constraint. - Dynamically adjusting the text size based on the available width using code instead of relying on the `autoSizeTextType` attribute.
By addressing these potential issues, you should be able to display the full text without truncation or ensure that the truncated text is visually indicated with an ellipsis.

how do i add a url to an xml file

In Android, you can add a URL to an XML file by using the `<data>` tag inside an `<intent-filter>` element. This is typically done in the `AndroidManifest.xml` file to handle incoming intents from other apps or web links.
Here's an example of how you can add a URL to your `AndroidManifest.xml` file:
```xml <activity android:name=".YourActivity"> <intent-filter> <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" /> <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" /> <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" /> <data android:host="www.example.com" android:pathPrefix="/path" android:scheme="https" /> </intent-filter> </activity> ```
In this example:
- `<action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />` specifies that this intent filter is for viewing data. - `<category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />` and `<category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />` are required for handling web links. - `<data>` tag specifies the URL pattern that your app can handle. - `android:host="www.example.com"` specifies the host part of the URL. - `android:pathPrefix="/path"` specifies the path prefix of the URL (optional). - `android:scheme="https"` specifies the scheme (protocol) of the URL.
With this configuration, your app will be able to handle URLs like `https://www.example.com/path/...` and open the specified `YourActivity` when such a URL is clicked.
Make sure to replace `YourActivity` with the actual name of your activity, and adjust the `android:host`, `android:pathPrefix`, and `android:scheme` values according to your requirements.
How to get a value from values @...\res\values\apiurl.xml

To get a value from a string resource file like `apiurl.xml` located in the `res/values` directory, you can use the `getString()` method provided by the Android framework.
Here's an example of how you can retrieve the value of the `test_url` string resource from `apiurl.xml` in your Kotlin code:
```kotlin val testUrl = getString(R.string.test_url) ```
However, you need to call this method from a context, such as an `Activity` or a `Fragment`. If you're in an `Activity` or a `Fragment`, you can directly call `getString()` like this:
```kotlin // Inside an Activity or Fragment val testUrl = getString(R.string.test_url) ```
If you're in a non-context class, like a utility class or a view model, you'll need to pass a `Context` instance to the `getString()` method. For example, if you're in a view model, you can get the `Context` from the `Application` instance:
```kotlin // Inside a ViewModel val testUrl = getApplication<Application>().getString(R.string.test_url) ```
Alternatively, you can pass the `Context` as a parameter to your non-context class from an `Activity` or a `Fragment`.
Make sure to import the required classes:
```kotlin import android.content.Context import androidx.core.content.ContextCompat ```
And then, you can use the `ContextCompat.getColor()` method to retrieve the string resource value:
```kotlin val testUrl = ContextCompat.getColor(context, R.string.test_url) ```
Replace `context` with the actual `Context` instance you have available.

The error `kotlin.UninitializedPropertyAccessException: lateinit property application has not been initialized` occurs because the `application` property is being accessed before it is initialized.
To fix this issue, you need to initialize the `application` property in the constructor of the `RetrofitInstance` class. Here's how you can modify the code:
1. Remove the `companion object` from the `RetrofitInstance` class and move its contents to the class body.
2. Initialize the `application` property in the constructor and use it to create the `retrofit` instance.
Here's the updated `RetrofitInstance.kt` file:
```kotlin package com.elis.orderingapplication.retrofit
import android.app.Application import com.elis.orderingapplication.R import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.OrderEvent import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.OrderInfo import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.UserLogOut import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.UserLogin import okhttp3.OkHttpClient import okhttp3.logging.HttpLoggingInterceptor import retrofit2.Retrofit import retrofit2.converter.gson.GsonConverterFactory import java.time.Duration import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit
class RetrofitInstance(private val application: Application) { private val retrofit: Retrofit by lazy { val logger = HttpLoggingInterceptor().setLevel(HttpLoggingInterceptor.Level.BODY)
val client = OkHttpClient.Builder() .addInterceptor(logger) .connectTimeout(Duration.ZERO) .writeTimeout(5, TimeUnit.MINUTES) .readTimeout(5, TimeUnit.MINUTES) .build()
val apiURL = application.getString(R.string.test_url)
Retrofit.Builder() .baseUrl(apiURL) .addConverterFactory(GsonConverterFactory.create()) .client(client) .build() }
val api by lazy { retrofit.create(UserLogin::class.java) } val api2 by lazy { retrofit.create(OrderInfo::class.java) } val orderEvent by lazy { retrofit.create(OrderEvent::class.java) } val logout by lazy { retrofit.create(UserLogOut::class.java) } } ```
Now, when you create an instance of `RetrofitInstance` by passing the `Application` instance, the `application` property will be initialized, and the `retrofit` instance will be created correctly.
```kotlin // In your Application class val retrofitInstance = RetrofitInstance(this)
// Or, in an Activity or Fragment val retrofitInstance = RetrofitInstance(requireActivity().application) ```
This should resolve the `kotlin.UninitializedPropertyAccessException` error.
Property delegate must have a 'getValue(RetroFitInstance.Companion, KProperty*>)' method. None of the following functions are suitable.

The error "Property delegate must have a 'getValue(RetroFitInstance.Companion, KProperty*)' method. None of the following functions are suitable" occurs because you are trying to use a delegate property (`by lazy`) inside a companion object, which is not allowed in Kotlin.
To fix this issue, you need to move the lazy initialization of the `retrofit` instance and the API instances (`api`, `api2`, `orderEvent`, `logout`) outside of the companion object.
Here's how you can modify the `RetrofitInstance.kt` file:
```kotlin package com.elis.orderingapplication.retrofit
import android.app.Application import com.elis.orderingapplication.R import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.OrderEvent import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.OrderInfo import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.UserLogOut import com.elis.orderingapplication.interfaces.UserLogin import okhttp3.OkHttpClient import okhttp3.logging.HttpLoggingInterceptor import retrofit2.Retrofit import retrofit2.converter.gson.GsonConverterFactory import java.time.Duration import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit
class RetrofitInstance(private val application: Application) { private val retrofit: Retrofit = createRetrofit(application)
private fun createRetrofit(application: Application): Retrofit { val logger = HttpLoggingInterceptor().setLevel(HttpLoggingInterceptor.Level.BODY)
val client = OkHttpClient.Builder() .addInterceptor(logger) .connectTimeout(Duration.ZERO) .writeTimeout(5, TimeUnit.MINUTES) .readTimeout(5, TimeUnit.MINUTES) .build()
val apiURL = application.getString(R.string.test_url)
return Retrofit.Builder() .baseUrl(apiURL) .addConverterFactory(GsonConverterFactory.create()) .client(client) .build() }
val api by lazy { retrofit.create(UserLogin::class.java) } val api2 by lazy { retrofit.create(OrderInfo::class.java) } val orderEvent by lazy { retrofit.create(OrderEvent::class.java) } val logout by lazy { retrofit.create(UserLogOut::class.java) } } ```
In this updated code:
1. The `retrofit` instance is created using a private function `createRetrofit` that takes the `Application` instance as a parameter. 2. The lazy initialization of the API instances (`api`, `api2`, `orderEvent`, `logout`) is moved outside of the companion object and uses the `retrofit` instance created in the constructor.
With this change, you should no longer encounter the "Property delegate must have a 'getValue(RetroFitInstance.Companion, KProperty*)' method" error.

How to Create a banner to show on every Fragment layout

To create a banner that shows on every Fragment layout in your Android app, you can create a custom view and include it in your Fragment layouts. Here's how you can do it:
1. Create a new layout file for your banner, e.g., `banner_layout.xml`, and place it in the `res/layout` directory. This layout file will contain the UI elements for your banner, such as a TextView or an ImageView.
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:background="@color/your_banner_background_color" android:orientation="vertical">
<TextView android:id="@+id/banner_text" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:layout_gravity="center_horizontal" android:text="@string/your_banner_text" android:textColor="@color/your_banner_text_color" android:textSize="16sp" />
</LinearLayout> ```
2. In your Fragment layouts, include the `banner_layout.xml` at the top or bottom of your layout, depending on where you want the banner to appear.
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:orientation="vertical">
<!-- Include your banner layout here --> <include layout="@layout/banner_layout" />
<!-- Your Fragment layout content goes here --> <!-- ... -->
</LinearLayout> ```
3. In your Fragment classes, you can access the views inside the `banner_layout.xml` and update them as needed. For example, if you want to change the banner text dynamically, you can do it in your Fragment's `onViewCreated` method:
```kotlin class YourFragment : Fragment() { override fun onViewCreated(view: View, savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { super.onViewCreated(view, savedInstanceState)
// Find the banner text view val bannerTextView = view.findViewById<TextView>(R.id.banner_text)
// Update the banner text bannerTextView.text = "Your dynamic banner text" }
// ... } ```
By including the `banner_layout.xml` in your Fragment layouts, the banner will be displayed on every Fragment in your app. You can customize the banner layout and update its content dynamically from your Fragment classes.
Note: If you want to show different banners or have different banner configurations for different Fragments, you can create separate layout files or use conditional logic in your Fragment classes to handle the banner display and content.
How to i use <include> with a constraint layout?

To use the `<include>` tag with a ConstraintLayout in your XML layout file, you need to wrap the `<include>` tag inside a `<ConstraintLayout>` or a `<ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>` element. This allows you to define constraints for the included layout within the parent ConstraintLayout.
Here's an example of how you can include your `banner_layout.xml` inside a ConstraintLayout:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent">
<!-- Include your banner layout here --> <ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints android:id="@+id/banner_container" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent">
<include android:id="@+id/banner_layout" layout="@layout/banner_layout" />
</ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>
<!-- Your Fragment layout content goes here --> <!-- ... -->
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
In this example:
1. We wrap the `<include>` tag inside a `<ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>` element, which allows us to define constraints for the included layout. 2. We set the `app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"` constraint on the `<ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>` element to position the included layout at the top of the parent ConstraintLayout. 3. You can add more constraints to the `<ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>` element to control the position and size of the included layout within the parent ConstraintLayout.
If you want to include the `banner_layout.xml` at the bottom of the ConstraintLayout, you can change the constraint to `app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"`.
By using the `<ConstraintLayout.LayoutConstraints>` element, you can include your `banner_layout.xml` or any other layout file within a ConstraintLayout and define constraints for it, just like you would for any other view in the ConstraintLayout.
Note: Make sure to include the `app` namespace (`xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"`) in your XML layout file to use the ConstraintLayout attributes.
How would i incluce another layout in @...\res\layout\fragment_login.xml ?

To include another layout in your `fragment_login.xml` file, you can use the `<include>` tag along with the `layout` attribute, which specifies the layout file you want to include.
Here's an example of how you can include your `banner_layout.xml` at the top of your `fragment_login.xml` file:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools" tools:context=".LoginFragment">
<data> <variable name="viewModel" type="com.elis.orderingapplication.viewModels.LoginViewModel" />

If you want to include the `banner_layout.xml` at the bottom of your `fragment_login.xml` layout, simply move the `<include>` tag to the bottom of the `<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>` element.
Note: Make sure to include the `app` namespace (`xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"`) in your XML layout file if you're using ConstraintLayout attributes.
I get the error Cannot resolve symbol '@layout/banner_layout'

The error "Cannot resolve symbol '@layout/banner_layout'" occurs when the Android Studio cannot find the specified layout file (`banner_layout.xml`) in your project's resources.
Here are a few steps you can take to resolve this issue:
1. **Check the file name and location**: Ensure that the `banner_layout.xml` file exists in the correct location, which should be `app/src/main/res/layout/banner_layout.xml`. Double-check the file name and path for any typos or capitalization issues.
2. **Clean and Rebuild the project**: Sometimes, Android Studio's caching mechanism can cause issues with resource resolution. Try cleaning and rebuilding your project: - Go to the "Build" menu - Select "Clean Project" - Once the cleaning process is complete, select "Rebuild Project"
3. **Invalidate Caches and Restart Android Studio**: If cleaning and rebuilding doesn't work, try invalidating the caches and restarting Android Studio: - Go to the "File" menu - Select "Invalidate Caches / Restart" - Click "Invalidate and Restart" in the dialog box
4. **Check for duplicate resource files**: Ensure that you don't have multiple `banner_layout.xml` files in different resource directories (e.g., `main`, `debug`, `release`). Android Studio may get confused about which file to use, causing the resolution error.
5. **Check resource merging**: If you're using product flavors or build variants, make sure that the `banner_layout.xml` file is present in the correct source set (e.g., `main`, `flavor1`, `flavor2`). Android Studio merges resources from different source sets, and if the file is missing in one of them, it may cause resolution issues.
6. **Check for resource conflicts**: Sometimes, resource conflicts can occur if you have third-party libraries or modules that include resources with the same name as your project's resources. Check for any potential conflicts and resolve them by renaming your resources or excluding the conflicting resources from the library/module.
If none of these steps resolve the issue, you may need to share more details about your project structure or provide additional context to help identify the root cause of the problem.
<include> cannot be used in Gradle 9

The error "`<include>` cannot be used in Gradle 9" is likely related to the Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) version you're using in your project. The `<include>` tag is used in XML layout files to include other layout files, but it seems that there's an issue with the way it's handled in Gradle 9.
To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:
1. **Update to the latest Android Gradle Plugin version**: - Open your project-level `build.gradle` file. - Find the `buildscript` block and update the `classpath` line to use the latest version of the Android Gradle Plugin. At the time of writing, the latest version is `8.2.0`:
```gradle buildscript { repositories { google() mavenCentral() } dependencies { classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:8.2.0' } } ```
2. **Sync your project with the Gradle files**: - After updating the Android Gradle Plugin version, sync your project with the Gradle files by clicking the "Sync Now" link in the notification bar or by going to "Tools" > "Android" > "Sync Project with Gradle Files".
3. **Clean and rebuild your project**: - Go to the "Build" menu in Android Studio. - Select "Clean Project". - Once the cleaning process is complete, select "Rebuild Project".
If updating the Android Gradle Plugin version doesn't resolve the issue, you can try the following alternative solutions:
1. **Use a merge layout technique**: Instead of using the `<include>` tag, you can create a separate layout file that includes the common elements (e.g., your banner layout) and the specific layout for each Fragment. Then, you can include this merged layout file in your Fragment layouts.
2. **Use a custom view**: Create a custom view class that encapsulates the banner layout and its functionality. Then, you can include this custom view in your Fragment layouts instead of using the `<include>` tag.
3. **Use a ViewStub**: The `ViewStub` class allows you to lazily inflate a layout when it's needed. You can use a `ViewStub` to include your banner layout in your Fragment layouts and inflate it when required.
If none of these solutions work, you may need to report the issue to the Android team or check for any updates or workarounds related to the specific version of the Android Gradle Plugin you're using.

android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher" looks pixelated

If the icon specified with `android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher"` looks pixelated, it could be due to one of the following reasons:
1. **Incorrect icon resolution or format**: The icon you provided might not have the correct resolution or format for different device densities. Android expects icons in different resolutions for different screen densities, such as mdpi, hdpi, xhdpi, xxhdpi, and xxxhdpi.
To fix this, you need to provide high-resolution icons in the appropriate mipmap folders. For example, create folders named `mipmap-mdpi`, `mipmap-hdpi`, `mipmap-xhdpi`, `mipmap-xxhdpi`, and `mipmap-xxxhdpi` in your `res` directory, and place the corresponding icon files in each folder with the appropriate resolution.
2. **Incorrect icon format**: Android recommends using PNG format for icons, as it supports transparency and provides better quality than other formats like JPEG or GIF.
If you're using a different format, try converting your icon to PNG and replace the existing files in the mipmap folders.
3. **Incorrect icon scaling**: If you're using vector drawable icons, make sure you're not scaling them incorrectly in your layout files or code. Vector drawables should be able to scale properly without losing quality.
4. **Incorrect icon rendering**: In some cases, the issue might be related to how the icon is rendered on the device or emulator. Try clearing the app data and cache, or uninstall and reinstall the app to see if it resolves the issue.
5. **Incorrect icon placement**: Ensure that you're placing the icon files in the correct mipmap folders and not in the drawable folders. The mipmap folders are specifically for launcher icons, while the drawable folders are for other graphics used in your app.
To resolve the pixelated icon issue, follow these steps:
1. Provide high-resolution icons in PNG format for different screen densities by placing them in the appropriate mipmap folders. 2. If you're using vector drawable icons, ensure they're not being scaled incorrectly. 3. Clear the app data and cache, or uninstall and reinstall the app. 4. If the issue persists, try using a different icon or check if there are any known issues with the specific device or emulator you're using.
By providing high-quality icons in the correct format and resolution, you should be able to resolve the pixelated icon issue and ensure that your app's icon looks sharp on different devices and screen densities.

Query still returning orders that have 0 totalArticles @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles != 0 ) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup """ )

The issue you're facing is that the query is not filtering out orders with `totalArticles` equal to 0 correctly. To fix this, you can modify the subquery that counts the orders to include an additional condition to exclude orders with `totalArticles` equal to 0.
Here's the updated query:
```kotlin @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup """ ) ```
The only change is in the subquery that counts the orders. Instead of using `pos_order.totalArticles != 0`, we use `pos_order.totalArticles > 0` to exclude orders with `totalArticles` equal to 0.
This should filter out orders with `totalArticles` equal to 0 from the result set.
Note: Make sure to clean and rebuild your project after making this change to ensure that the new query is applied correctly.

How to use this query to filter out pos_orders and return points_of_service that have > 0 totalArticles? @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0 ) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup """ ) fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String, orderDate: String ): LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>>

To filter out `pos_orders` and return only `points_of_service` that have `totalArticles` greater than 0, you can modify the query to include a `HAVING` clause. The `HAVING` clause allows you to filter the result set based on a condition involving aggregate functions like `COUNT`.
Here's the updated query:
```kotlin @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup HAVING totalOrders > 0 """ ) fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String, orderDate: String ): LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>> ```
The added `HAVING totalOrders > 0` clause filters the result set to include only `points_of_service` records where the `totalOrders` subquery returns a value greater than 0. This effectively excludes `points_of_service` records that have no associated `pos_orders` with `totalArticles` greater than 0.
With this modification, the query will return a `LiveData` list of `PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders` objects, where each object represents a `points_of_service` record that has at least one associated `pos_order` with `totalArticles` greater than 0.
Note: Make sure to clean and rebuild your project after making this change to ensure that the new query is applied correctly.
<compound operator>, BETWEEN, GROUP, IN, LIMIT, ORDER or semicolon expected, got 'HAVING'

The error "`<compound operator>, BETWEEN, GROUP, IN, LIMIT, ORDER or semicolon expected, got 'HAVING'`" occurs because the `HAVING` clause is not allowed in the same query level as the `SELECT` statement in Room. The `HAVING` clause is used with aggregate functions like `SUM`, `COUNT`, `AVG`, etc., and it should be used after the `GROUP BY` clause.
To fix this issue, you can modify your query to use a subquery with the `HAVING` clause, and then select from the subquery in the outer query. Here's how you can modify your query:
```kotlin @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT * FROM ( SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup ) WHERE totalOrders > 0 """ ) fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String, orderDate: String ): LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>> ```
In this modified query:
1. The original query is wrapped inside a subquery using the `FROM (...)` syntax. 2. The `HAVING` clause is removed from the subquery. 3. The outer query selects `*` (all columns) from the subquery. 4. The `WHERE totalOrders > 0` clause is added to the outer query to filter the result set based on the `totalOrders` value.
This way, the `HAVING` clause is not used directly in the same query level as the `SELECT` statement, which should resolve the error you're encountering.
Note: Make sure to clean and rebuild your project after making this change to ensure that the new query is applied correctly.
totalPOS is including the filtered out totalOrders that == 0

To exclude `points_of_service` records where `totalOrders` is 0 from the `totalPOS` count, you can modify the subquery that calculates `totalPOS` to include a condition that checks for `totalOrders > 0`.
Here's the updated query:
```kotlin @Transaction @Query( """ SELECT * FROM ( SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service p WHERE p.deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND p.orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup AND (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = p.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = p.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) > 0) AS totalPOS, points_of_service.*, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = points_of_service.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = points_of_service.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) AS totalOrders FROM points_of_service WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup ) WHERE totalOrders > 0 """ ) fun getPointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders( deliveryAddressNo: String, orderingGroup: String, orderDate: String ): LiveData<List<PointsOfServiceWithTotalOrders>> ```
In this updated query, the subquery that calculates `totalPOS` has been modified to include a nested subquery that checks if there are any `pos_order` records with `totalArticles > 0` for the current `points_of_service` record. The `COUNT(*)` for `totalPOS` is calculated only for `points_of_service` records where this nested subquery returns a value greater than 0.
Here's a breakdown of the changes:
```sql (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM points_of_service p WHERE p.deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND p.orderingGroupNo = :orderingGroup AND (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM pos_order WHERE pos_order.point_of_service_no = p.point_of_service AND pos_order.deliveryAddressNo = p.deliveryAddressNo AND pos_order.orderDate = :orderDate AND pos_order.orderType == "inventory" AND pos_order.totalArticles > 0) > 0) AS totalPOS ```
This subquery calculates `totalPOS` by counting the number of `points_of_service` records that have at least one associated `pos_order` record with `totalArticles > 0`.
With this modification, the `totalPOS` count should exclude `points_of_service` records that have no associated `pos_order` records with `totalArticles > 0`.
Note: Make sure to clean and rebuild your project after making this change to ensure that the new query is applied correctly.
