i now get the following error after modifying my code One type argument expected. Use 'Success<*>' if you don't want to pass type arguments

The error "One type argument expected. Use 'Success<*>' if you don't want to pass type arguments" is likely occurring because the `ApiResponse` class is a generic class, and you need to specify the type parameter when creating instances of its subclasses.
In your case, the `ApiResponse.Success` class is a subclass of `ApiResponse`, and it expects a type parameter to be specified. Here's how you can fix the issue:
1. Update the `ApiResponse.Success` class to include the type parameter:
```kotlin class Success<T>(data: T) : ApiResponse<T>(data) ```
2. When creating instances of `ApiResponse.Success`, provide the type parameter:
```kotlin when (response) { is ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse> -> handleSuccessResponse(response.data?.success) is ApiResponse.Loading -> handleLoadingState() is ApiResponse.Error -> handleErrorResponse(response.message) is ApiResponse.ErrorSendOrderDate -> handleErrorResponse(response.message) is ApiResponse.NoDataError -> handleNoDataError() is ApiResponse.ErrorLogin -> handleUnknownError() is ApiResponse.UnknownError -> handleUnknownError() else -> handleUnknownError() } ```
In this example, we're specifying the type parameter `OrderEventResponse` for `ApiResponse.Success`. This means that the `data` property of `ApiResponse.Success` will be of type `OrderEventResponse`.
If you're not sure what type to use for the type parameter, you can use the wildcard `*` to indicate that you don't want to specify a specific type:
```kotlin when (response) { is ApiResponse.Success<*> -> handleSuccessResponse(response.data?.success) // ... } ```
However, using the wildcard `*` means that you won't have access to the properties of the `data` object, as its type is unknown.
By specifying the type parameter for `ApiResponse.Success`, you should be able to resolve the "One type argument expected" error.

I've changed that but now i get the follpowing error Cannot check for instance of erased type: ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse>

The error "Cannot check for instance of erased type: ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse>" occurs because of type erasure in Kotlin/Java. Type erasure is a process where the type information is removed at runtime to ensure backward compatibility with older versions of Java.
When you use a generic type like `ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse>`, the type parameter `OrderEventResponse` is erased at runtime, and the JVM treats it as a raw type (`ApiResponse.Success`). This means that the JVM cannot distinguish between different instantiations of the generic type, making it impossible to perform instance checks based on the type parameter.
To resolve this issue, you can use the `is` operator with the `Any` type and then perform a smart cast to the desired type. Here's how you can modify your code:
```kotlin private fun sendOrderToSOL(order: Order, externalOrderId: String = externalOrderId()) { val sendOrder = articleEntryViewModel.sendOrderToSOL(order, externalOrderId) val sendOrderEvent = OrderEvent(sharedViewModel.getSessionKey(), sendOrder) when (val response = articleEntryViewModel.orderEvent(sendOrderEvent)) { is ApiResponse.Success -> { val successResponse = response as ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse> handleSuccessResponse(successResponse.data?.success) } is ApiResponse.Loading -> handleLoadingState() is ApiResponse.Error -> handleErrorResponse(response.message) is ApiResponse.ErrorSendOrderDate -> handleErrorResponse(response.message) is ApiResponse.NoDataError -> handleNoDataError() is ApiResponse.ErrorLogin -> handleUnknownError() is ApiResponse.UnknownError -> handleUnknownError() else -> handleUnknownError() } } ```
In this modified code, we're using the `is` operator with the `Any` type (`is ApiResponse.Success`) to check if the `response` is an instance of `ApiResponse.Success`. If it is, we perform a smart cast (`val successResponse = response as ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse>`) to the desired type `ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse>`. This way, we can access the `data` property of `successResponse` and handle the success response correctly.
By using smart casts, you can work around the type erasure issue and handle the different cases of the `ApiResponse` correctly.
Alternatively, you can use the `when` subject in Kotlin to avoid the type erasure issue:
```kotlin private fun sendOrderToSOL(order: Order, externalOrderId: String = externalOrderId()) { val sendOrder = articleEntryViewModel.sendOrderToSOL(order, externalOrderId) val sendOrderEvent = OrderEvent(sharedViewModel.getSessionKey(), sendOrder) when (val apiResponse = articleEntryViewModel.orderEvent(sendOrderEvent)) { is ApiResponse.Success<OrderEventResponse> -> handleSuccessResponse(apiResponse.data?.success) is ApiResponse.Loading -> handleLoadingState() is ApiResponse.Error -> handleErrorResponse(apiResponse.message) is ApiResponse.ErrorSendOrderDate -> handleErrorResponse(apiResponse.message) is ApiResponse.NoDataError -> handleNoDataError() is ApiResponse.ErrorLogin -> handleUnknownError() is ApiResponse.UnknownError -> handleUnknownError() else -> handleUnknownError() } } ```
In this approach, we're using the `when` subject (`when (val apiResponse = response)`) to capture the value of `response` in a new variable `apiResponse`. This way, the type parameter is preserved, and you can handle the different cases of `ApiResponse` correctly without encountering the type erasure issue.
Both approaches should resolve the "Cannot check for instance of erased type" error and allow you to handle the different cases of `ApiResponse` correctly.

Is it possible to make my app adaptable to different screen sizes? Varying mobile devices?

Yes, it is possible to make your Android app adaptable to different screen sizes and varying mobile devices. Android provides several techniques and best practices to achieve this, ensuring that your app looks and functions correctly across a wide range of devices and screen sizes.
Here are some common approaches to make your app adaptable:
1. **Use Responsive Layout Design**: - Utilize layout resources like `dp` (density-independent pixels) instead of hard-coded pixel values for dimensions and sizes. This ensures that your UI elements scale appropriately on different screen densities. - Leverage layout containers like `ConstraintLayout`, `LinearLayout`, and `RelativeLayout` to create flexible and responsive layouts that can adapt to different screen sizes. - Use layout weights and layout constraints to control how your UI elements resize and reposition based on the available screen space.
2. **Provide Alternative Layout Resources**: - Create different layout resource files for different screen sizes and orientations. Android allows you to provide different layout files for different screen configurations using qualifiers (e.g., `layout-sw600dp` for screens wider than 600dp). - At runtime, Android will automatically load the appropriate layout resource based on the device's screen configuration.
3. **Use Dimension Resources**: - Define dimension values (e.g., margins, paddings, text sizes) in `dimens.xml` files instead of hard-coding them in your layouts. - Provide alternative `dimens.xml` files for different screen configurations using qualifiers, similar to layout resources.
4. **Leverage Vector Assets**: - Use vector drawable assets (`.xml` files) instead of raster images (`.png`, `.jpg`) for icons, logos, and other graphical elements. - Vector assets can scale without losing quality, ensuring sharp and crisp visuals on different screen densities.
5. **Implement Adaptive UI Components**: - Use Android's built-in adaptive UI components like `RecyclerView`, `GridLayout`, and `PercentRelativeLayout`, which can automatically adjust their layout and content based on the available screen space. - Customize the behavior of these components using attributes and callbacks to fine-tune the adaptation for your specific use case.
6. **Test on Different Devices and Emulators**: - Use the Android Virtual Device (AVD) emulators to test your app on various screen sizes and configurations during development. - Consider using tools like Genymotion or physical device labs to test your app on a wide range of real devices.
7. **Follow Android's Material Design Guidelines**: - Adhere to the Material Design guidelines provided by Google, which offer recommendations and best practices for creating adaptive and responsive user interfaces.
By following these techniques and best practices, you can ensure that your Android app looks and functions correctly across a wide range of devices and screen sizes, providing a consistent and optimal user experience for your users.
My splash screen isn't showing, just an app icon?

There could be a few reasons why your splash screen is not showing and only the app icon is visible:
1. **Splash Screen Implementation**: Make sure you have correctly implemented the splash screen in your app. In the `MainActivity.kt` file, you have imported `androidx.core.splashscreen.SplashScreen.Companion.installSplashScreen`, but you don't seem to be using it anywhere in the code. You need to call `installSplashScreen()` in the `onCreate` method of your `MainActivity` to show the splash screen.
2. **Splash Screen Resources**: Ensure that you have provided the required resources for the splash screen. You need to have a drawable resource (e.g., `drawable/splash.xml`) that defines the splash screen layout and appearance.
3. **Theme Configuration**: Check if your app's theme is correctly configured to show the splash screen. In your `styles.xml` file, you should have a theme that extends `Theme.SplashScreen` or `Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground` and applies the splash screen drawable.
4. **Splash Screen Duration**: The splash screen might be showing but disappearing too quickly. By default, the splash screen is displayed until the app is initialized. If your app initialization is too fast, the splash screen might not be visible for long enough. You can adjust the splash screen duration by calling `setSplashScreenDurationMillis` on the `SplashScreen` instance.
5. **API Level Compatibility**: The `SplashScreen` API was introduced in Android 12 (API level 31). If you're targeting lower API levels, you might need to use a different approach for implementing the splash screen, such as showing a separate `SplashActivity` or using a library like `androidx.core.app.ActivityCompat.startActivityForResult`.
To troubleshoot further, you can add logging or breakpoints in your `MainActivity` to ensure that the splash screen code is being executed correctly. Additionally, you can check the Android documentation on [Splash Screens](https://developer.android.com/develop/ui/views/launch/splash-screen) for more information and examples.
Why does my splash screen icon show with rounded corners?

The rounded corners on your splash screen icon are likely due to the way the icon is being rendered or the configuration of the splash screen theme.
By default, Android applies a rounded mask to app icons to give them a more modern and consistent look across the system. This behavior is controlled by the `roundIcon` attribute in your app's manifest file.
To prevent the rounded corners on your splash screen icon, you can try the following:
1. **Use a dedicated splash screen drawable**: Instead of using the app icon as the splash screen, create a dedicated drawable resource (e.g., `drawable/splash.xml`) for your splash screen. This drawable can be a layered vector or an image without any rounded corners applied.
2. **Configure the splash screen theme**: In your `styles.xml` file, make sure the theme you're using for the splash screen extends `Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground` and sets the `windowSplashScreenIconBackgroundColor` attribute to a solid color or a drawable that matches your splash screen background.
Example:
```xml <style name="SplashScreenTheme" parent="Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground"> <item name="windowSplashScreenIconBackgroundColor">@color/your_splash_screen_background</item> </style> ```
By setting a solid background color or a drawable that matches your splash screen background, the icon will be rendered without any rounded corners.
3. **Use a transparent splash screen icon**: If you want to use your app icon as the splash screen, you can create a transparent version of your icon (e.g., `drawable/splash_icon.xml`) and set it as the splash screen icon using the `windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon` attribute in your splash screen theme.
Example:
```xml <style name="SplashScreenTheme" parent="Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground"> <item name="windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon">@drawable/splash_icon</item> <item name="windowSplashScreenIconBackgroundColor">@color/your_splash_screen_background</item> </style> ```
By using a transparent icon and setting a solid background color, the icon will be rendered without rounded corners.
These approaches should help you remove the rounded corners from your splash screen icon and achieve the desired appearance.
Why does my splashscreen icon have rounded corners? @...\res\values\themes.xml and @...\src\main\AndroidManifest.xml

After reviewing the provided code snippets, it seems that the rounded corners on your splash screen icon are likely due to the way the app icon is being rendered by default on Android.
In your `AndroidManifest.xml` file, you have specified the app icon using the `android:icon` and `android:roundIcon` attributes:
```xml <application android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher" android:roundIcon="@mipmap/ic_launcher_round" ...> ```
The `android:roundIcon` attribute is used to specify a rounded version of your app icon, which is used in certain contexts, such as the app launcher, overview screen, and other system surfaces that display rounded icons.
However, when you use the `windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon` attribute in your splash screen theme, Android will use the rounded version of your app icon (`ic_launcher_round`) by default, resulting in the rounded corners on your splash screen.
To remove the rounded corners from your splash screen icon, you can try one of the following approaches:
1. **Use a dedicated splash screen icon**: Create a separate drawable resource (e.g., `drawable/splash_icon.xml`) for your splash screen icon, and set it using the `windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon` attribute in your splash screen theme. Make sure this drawable does not have rounded corners.
```xml <style name="SplashScreenTheme" parent="Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground"> <item name="windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon">@drawable/splash_icon</item> <!-- Other splash screen theme attributes --> </style> ```
2. **Use a transparent version of your app icon**: If you want to use your app icon as the splash screen icon, create a transparent version of your app icon (e.g., `drawable/splash_icon_transparent.xml`) and set it as the splash screen icon using the `windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon` attribute.
```xml <style name="SplashScreenTheme" parent="Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground"> <item name="windowSplashScreenAnimatedIcon">@drawable/splash_icon_transparent</item> <!-- Other splash screen theme attributes --> </style> ```
By using a transparent icon, the rounded corners will not be visible, and the icon will be rendered with a square shape.
3. **Set a solid background color for the splash screen icon**: If you want to use your app icon as the splash screen icon, you can set a solid background color for the splash screen icon using the `windowSplashScreenIconBackgroundColor` attribute in your splash screen theme. This will create a square background behind the icon, effectively removing the rounded corners.
```xml <style name="SplashScreenTheme" parent="Theme.SplashScreen.IconBackground"> <item name="windowSplashScreenIconBackgroundColor">@color/your_splash_screen_background</item> <!-- Other splash screen theme attributes --> </style> ```
By using one of these approaches, you should be able to remove the rounded corners from your splash screen icon and achieve the desired appearance.

How to create a layout for a phone and tablet?

To create a layout that works well for both phones and tablets in the provided codebase, you can follow these steps:
1. **Create separate layout files for different screen sizes**: - Create a layout file for phones (e.g., `fragment_login.xml`) in the `res/layout` directory. - Create a layout file for tablets (e.g., `fragment_login_tablet.xml`) in the `res/layout-sw600dp` directory. This directory is for layouts specific to screens with a minimum width of 600dp, which typically includes tablets.
2. **Use different layout structures or constraints for phones and tablets**: - In the phone layout (`fragment_login.xml`), you can use a vertical layout structure or constraints suitable for smaller screens. - In the tablet layout (`fragment_login_tablet.xml`), you can use a horizontal layout structure or constraints to take advantage of the larger screen real estate.
3. **Utilize different layout components or sizes for different screen sizes**: - For phones, you might want to use smaller UI components or adjust their sizes accordingly. - For tablets, you can use larger UI components or increase their sizes to make better use of the available space.
4. **Leverage layout weights or guidelines for flexible layouts**: - Use layout weights or guidelines to create flexible layouts that can adapt to different screen sizes and orientations. - For example, in the tablet layout, you could use a horizontal `LinearLayout` with layout weights to distribute UI components evenly across the screen.
5. **Provide alternative layouts for landscape orientation (optional)**: - If needed, you can create additional layout files for landscape orientation by creating directories like `res/layout-land` for phones and `res/layout-sw600dp-land` for tablets.
By following these steps, you can create separate layouts optimized for phones and tablets, ensuring a better user experience on different screen sizes. The Android system will automatically load the appropriate layout based on the device's screen size and orientation.
It's important to note that you should test your layouts on various devices and emulators to ensure they look and function as intended across different screen sizes and orientations.
how to use res/layout-sw600dp layouts?

Based on the provided codebase context, there are no separate layout files for tablets (res/layout-sw600dp) included. However, if you want to create and use separate layouts for tablets, you can follow these steps:
1. Create a new directory called `res/layout-sw600dp` in your project's `app/src/main/res` folder. This directory is where you'll place the layout files specifically for tablets and larger screens with a minimum width of 600dp.
2. Copy the existing layout files (e.g., `fragment_login.xml`, `fragment_article.xml`, `fragment_order.xml`, etc.) from the `res/layout` directory to the `res/layout-sw600dp` directory.
3. In the copied layout files within the `res/layout-sw600dp` directory, modify the layout structure, constraints, and UI components as needed to optimize them for larger screens.
For example, in `fragment_login_tablet.xml` (copied from `fragment_login.xml`), you could use a horizontal `LinearLayout` or adjust the `ConstraintLayout` constraints to position the UI elements differently for a tablet layout.
4. In your Fragment classes (e.g., `LoginFragment`, `ArticleFragment`, `OrderFragment`, etc.), you don't need to make any changes to the code. The Android system will automatically load the appropriate layout file based on the device's screen size.
- For devices with a screen width smaller than 600dp (phones), the layouts from `res/layout` will be used. - For devices with a screen width of 600dp or larger (tablets), the layouts from `res/layout-sw600dp` will be used.
5. Build and run your app on different devices or emulators to ensure that the correct layouts are being loaded and displayed properly for phones and tablets.
By following these steps, you can create separate layouts optimized for tablets and larger screens without modifying your existing code. The Android system will automatically load the appropriate layout based on the device's screen size, providing an optimized user experience for both phones and tablets.
Note: If you want to create separate layouts for landscape orientation as well, you can create additional directories like `res/layout-land` for phones and `res/layout-sw600dp-land` for tablets in landscape mode.

Based on the provided codebase context, you can add an icon button to the `MaterialToolbar` by using the `app:navigationIcon` attribute. Here's how you can modify the `MaterialToolbar` XML code:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" style="@style/overflowMenuColour" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="@color/elis_blue" app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:navigationContentDescription="@string/go_back_to_options" app:navigationIcon="@drawable/your_icon_drawable" app:titleTextAppearance="@style/Toolbar.TitleText" /> ```
Replace `@drawable/your_icon_drawable` with the actual drawable resource name for the icon you want to use. Make sure to place the icon drawable file in the appropriate `res/drawable` directory.
If you want to add an icon button on the opposite side of the navigation icon (typically the right side), you can use the `app:menu` attribute and define a menu resource file with the desired icon item. Here's an example:
1. Create a new menu resource file, e.g., `res/menu/toolbar_menu.xml`, and define the icon item:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <menu xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"> <item android:id="@+id/action_icon" android:icon="@drawable/your_icon_drawable" android:title="Icon Button" app:showAsAction="always" /> </menu> ```
2. In your `MaterialToolbar` XML code, add the `app:menu` attribute and reference the menu resource file:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" style="@style/overflowMenuColour" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="@color/elis_blue" app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:menu="@menu/toolbar_menu" app:navigationContentDescription="@string/go_back_to_options" app:navigationIcon="@drawable/your_icon_drawable" app:titleTextAppearance="@style/Toolbar.TitleText" /> ```
In your Fragment or Activity code, you can handle the icon button click event by setting an `OnMenuItemClickListener` on the `MaterialToolbar`.
By following these steps, you can add an icon button to the `MaterialToolbar` in your layout, either as a navigation icon or as a menu item on the opposite side.
How to i change position of new menu item?

Based on the provided codebase context, you can change the position of the new menu item by modifying the `app:menuGravity` attribute of the `MaterialToolbar`. Here's how you can do it:
1. First, create a new menu resource file, e.g., `res/menu/toolbar_menu.xml`, and define the menu item:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <menu xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"> <item android:id="@+id/action_icon" android:icon="@drawable/your_icon_drawable" android:title="Icon Button" app:showAsAction="always" /> </menu> ```
2. In your layout file (e.g., `fragment_login.xml`), modify the `MaterialToolbar` XML code to include the `app:menu` attribute and reference the menu resource file:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" style="@style/overflowMenuColour" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="@color/elis_blue" app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:menu="@menu/toolbar_menu" app:menuGravity="end" <!-- Change the position of the menu item --> app:navigationContentDescription="@string/go_back_to_options" app:navigationIcon="@drawable/your_icon_drawable" app:titleTextAppearance="@style/Toolbar.TitleText" /> ```
3. The `app:menuGravity` attribute determines the position of the menu items in the `MaterialToolbar`. By default, it is set to `start`, which places the menu items on the left side of the toolbar.
To change the position of the new menu item, you can set the `app:menuGravity` attribute to one of the following values:
- `start`: Places the menu items on the left side of the toolbar (default). - `end`: Places the menu items on the right side of the toolbar. - `center`: Places the menu items in the center of the toolbar.
For example, to place the new menu item on the right side of the toolbar, set `app:menuGravity="end"` as shown in the code above.
By modifying the `app:menuGravity` attribute, you can control the position of the new menu item in the `MaterialToolbar`. Make sure to handle the menu item click event in your Fragment or Activity code by setting an `OnMenuItemClickListener` on the `MaterialToolbar`.

How would i create a app tool bar in @...\elis\orderingapplication\MainActivity.kt to use across all my Fragments?

Based on the provided codebase context, you can create an app toolbar in the `MainActivity.kt` file and use it across all your Fragments by following these steps:
1. In the `activity_main.xml` layout file, add a `Toolbar` element at the top of the layout:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent">
<androidx.appcompat.widget.Toolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="?attr/colorPrimary" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:titleTextColor="@android:color/white" />
<fragment android:id="@+id/myNavHostFragment" android:name="androidx.navigation.fragment.NavHostFragment" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="0dp" app:defaultNavHost="true" app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@+id/toolbar" />
</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
2. In the `MainActivity.kt` file, bind the `Toolbar` with the `ActivityMainBinding` and set it as the app's `ActionBar`:
```kotlin class MainActivity : AppCompatActivity(), MenuHost { private lateinit var binding: ActivityMainBinding private lateinit var navController: NavController
override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { installSplashScreen() super.onCreate(savedInstanceState) binding = ActivityMainBinding.inflate(layoutInflater) setContentView(binding.root) navController = findNavController(R.id.myNavHostFragment)
// Set up the Toolbar setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) supportActionBar?.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true) setupActionBarWithNavController(this, navController) }
override fun onSupportNavigateUp(): Boolean { return navController.navigateUp() || super.onSupportNavigateUp() } } ```
3. In your Fragment layouts, you can now remove any existing `Toolbar` or `MaterialToolbar` elements, as the app toolbar will be provided by the `MainActivity`.
4. If you need to customize the app toolbar for specific Fragments, you can do so by overriding the `onCreateOptionsMenu` and `onOptionsItemSelected` methods in your Fragment classes and inflating the desired menu resources or handling menu item clicks.
By following these steps, you will have a consistent app toolbar across all your Fragments, managed by the `MainActivity`. The `Toolbar` will be displayed at the top of the screen, and you can customize its appearance and behavior as needed.
Note: Make sure to import the necessary classes and packages, such as `androidx.appcompat.widget.Toolbar`, `androidx.navigation.NavController`, and `androidx.navigation.ui.setupActionBarWithNavController`.

To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:
1. In the `MainActivity.kt` file, add the following code in the `onCreate` method after setting up the `navController`:
```kotlin val navHostFragment = supportFragmentManager.findFragmentById(R.id.myNavHostFragment) as NavHostFragment val navController = navHostFragment.navController val navInflater = navController.navInflater val graph = navInflater.inflate(R.navigation.navigation) navController.graph = graph ```

How do i style the toolbar?

Based on the provided codebase context, you can style the toolbar by creating a custom style in your project's `styles.xml` file or by defining styles directly in your layout files.
Here's an example of how you can create a custom style for the toolbar in the `styles.xml` file:
1. Open the `styles.xml` file located in the `app/src/main/res/values` directory.
2. Add a new style for the toolbar, for example:
```xml <style name="CustomToolbarStyle" parent="Widget.MaterialComponents.Toolbar"> <item name="android:background">@color/elis_blue</item> <item name="titleTextColor">@color/white</item> <item name="subtitleTextColor">@color/white</item> <item name="android:elevation">4dp</item> </style> ```
This style inherits from the `Widget.MaterialComponents.Toolbar` style and overrides various attributes like background color, text colors, and elevation.
3. In your layout file (e.g., `activity_main.xml`), apply the custom style to the `Toolbar` or `MaterialToolbar` by setting the `style` attribute:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" style="@style/CustomToolbarStyle" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" /> ```
Alternatively, you can define styles directly in your layout files using the `style` attribute and specifying the desired attributes:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" style="@style/Widget.MaterialComponents.Toolbar" app:titleTextColor="@color/white" app:subtitleTextColor="@color/white" android:background="@color/elis_blue" android:elevation="4dp" /> ```
In this example, the `MaterialToolbar` is styled directly in the layout file by setting attributes like `titleTextColor`, `subtitleTextColor`, `background`, and `elevation`.
By using either approach (custom styles or inline styles), you can customize the appearance of the toolbar to match your app's design requirements.
Note: Make sure to define the color resources (e.g., `@color/elis_blue`, `@color/white`) in your project's `colors.xml` file or use existing color resources from the provided codebase context.
How to change toolbar navigationicon?

Based on the provided codebase context, you can change the navigation icon of the toolbar by modifying the `activity_main.xml` layout file.
In the `activity_main.xml` file, the `Toolbar` is defined as follows:
```xml <com.google.android.material.appbar.AppBarLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf="parent" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent">
<androidx.appcompat.widget.Toolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="@color/elis_blue" app:menu="@menu/toolbar_menu"/>
</com.google.android.material.appbar.AppBarLayout> ```
To change the navigation icon, you can add the `app:navigationIcon` attribute to the `Toolbar` and provide the desired drawable resource:
```xml <androidx.appcompat.widget.Toolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" android:background="@color/elis_blue" app:menu="@menu/toolbar_menu" app:navigationIcon="@drawable/your_navigation_icon" /> ```
Replace `@drawable/your_navigation_icon` with the actual drawable resource name for the icon you want to use as the navigation icon.
Alternatively, if you want to change the navigation icon programmatically, you can modify the `MainActivity.kt` file and set the navigation icon in the `onCreate` method:
```kotlin override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { // ... setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) supportActionBar?.setNavigationIcon(R.drawable.your_navigation_icon) // ... } ```
Again, replace `R.drawable.your_navigation_icon` with the actual drawable resource name for the icon you want to use as the navigation icon.
By following either of these approaches, you can change the navigation icon of the toolbar based on the provided codebase context, without making any assumptions.
Note: Make sure that the drawable resource you specify (`@drawable/your_navigation_icon`) exists in the project's `res/drawable` directory or any other appropriate drawable resource directory.

Based on the provided codebase context, the issue with the toolbar not being styled correctly might be due to conflicting styles and attribute overrides.
In the `activity_main.xml` layout file, you have defined the `MaterialToolbar` with the `CustomToolbarStyle` style and also set some attributes directly on the `MaterialToolbar` element, such as `android:background` and `app:titleTextColor`.
When you set attributes directly on a view element, they take precedence over the styles defined in the `styles.xml` file. This means that the `android:background` and `app:titleTextColor` attributes you set on the `MaterialToolbar` element will override the corresponding values defined in the `CustomToolbarStyle`.
To resolve this issue, you can remove the conflicting attributes from the `MaterialToolbar` element in the layout file and rely solely on the `CustomToolbarStyle` to style the toolbar. Here's how you can modify the `activity_main.xml` file:
```xml <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" tools:context=".MainActivity">
<com.google.android.material.appbar.MaterialToolbar android:id="@+id/toolbar" style="@style/CustomToolbarStyle" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:menu="@menu/toolbar_menu" />
<fragment android:id="@+id/myNavHostFragment" android:name="androidx.navigation.fragment.NavHostFragment" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="0dp" app:defaultNavHost="true" app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@+id/toolbar" app:navGraph="@navigation/navigation" /> </androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> ```
In this modified layout file, the `android:background` and `app:titleTextColor` attributes have been removed from the `MaterialToolbar` element, allowing the `CustomToolbarStyle` to take effect without any conflicts.
With this change, the `CustomToolbarStyle` should correctly style the toolbar, including the navigation icon, background color, text colors, and other attributes defined in the style.

How to i set a toolbar title per Fragment?

Based on the provided codebase context, there is no specific implementation or code snippet that demonstrates how to set the toolbar title per Fragment.
However, you can set the toolbar title per Fragment by overriding the `onCreateOptionsMenu` and `onPrepareOptionsMenu` methods in your Fragment class.
Here's an example of how you can implement this:
1. In your Fragment class, override the `onCreateOptionsMenu` method to inflate the menu resource:
```kotlin override fun onCreateOptionsMenu(menu: Menu, inflater: MenuInflater) { inflater.inflate(R.menu.your_menu_resource, menu) super.onCreateOptionsMenu(menu, inflater) } ```
2. In your Fragment class, override the `onPrepareOptionsMenu` method to set the toolbar title:
```kotlin override fun onPrepareOptionsMenu(menu: Menu) { val toolbar = (requireActivity() as AppCompatActivity).supportActionBar toolbar?.title = "Your Toolbar Title" super.onPrepareOptionsMenu(menu) } ```
Replace `"Your Toolbar Title"` with the desired title for the toolbar in that specific Fragment.
3. Make sure to import the necessary classes and packages, such as `android.view.Menu`, `android.view.MenuInflater`, `androidx.appcompat.app.AppCompatActivity`, and `androidx.core.view.isVisible`.
By overriding these methods in your Fragment class, you can set the toolbar title dynamically for each Fragment. The `onCreateOptionsMenu` method inflates the menu resource, and the `onPrepareOptionsMenu` method sets the toolbar title using the `supportActionBar?.title` property.
Note: This approach assumes that you have set up the toolbar in the `MainActivity` or the hosting activity, and the toolbar is visible in your Fragments.
If you need to set the toolbar title based on specific conditions or data within the Fragment, you can modify the `onPrepareOptionsMenu` method accordingly.
Without making any assumptions and based solely on the provided codebase context, this is the recommended approach to set the toolbar title per Fragment. If you need further assistance or have any specific requirements, please provide more context or code snippets related to your Fragment implementation.

2. In the `MainActivity.kt` file, set up the Toolbar as the app's ActionBar:
```kotlin override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { // ... binding = ActivityMainBinding.inflate(layoutInflater) setContentView(binding.root) // ... setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) // ... } ```
3. Ensure that the Toolbar is visible in all Fragments by not hiding or overlapping it with other UI elements.
4. If you need to customize the Toolbar for specific Fragments (e.g., setting the title, menu items, etc.), you can override the `onCreateOptionsMenu` and `onPrepareOptionsMenu` methods in your Fragment classes.
By following these steps, the custom Toolbar defined in the `activity_main.xml` layout file and set up in the `MainActivity.kt` file will be visible across all Fragments hosted within the `MainActivity`.

Difference between Toolbar and MaterialToolbar?

Based on the provided codebase context, there is no explicit information or code snippets that explain the difference between `Toolbar` and `MaterialToolbar`. However, I can provide a general explanation based on the Android documentation and best practices.
The `Toolbar` is a ViewGroup that is part of the Android Support Library (now called AndroidX). It was introduced as a replacement for the traditional `ActionBar` and provides a flexible and customizable way to display navigation and action items in an app.
On the other hand, the `MaterialToolbar` is a part of the Material Components for Android library, which is a separate library from the Android Support Library. The `MaterialToolbar` is a specialized implementation of the `Toolbar` that follows the Material Design guidelines and provides additional features and styling options specific to the Material Design language.
While both `Toolbar` and `MaterialToolbar` serve similar purposes (displaying navigation and action items), the `MaterialToolbar` is designed to provide a more consistent and visually appealing experience that aligns with the Material Design principles.
Here are some key differences between `Toolbar` and `MaterialToolbar`:
1. **Design and Styling**: The `MaterialToolbar` follows the Material Design guidelines and provides built-in styling options that adhere to the Material Design principles. The `Toolbar`, on the other hand, requires more manual styling to achieve a similar look and feel.
2. **Material Components Library**: The `MaterialToolbar` is part of the Material Components for Android library, which provides a comprehensive set of components and utilities for building Material Design-compliant user interfaces. The `Toolbar` is part of the Android Support Library, which has a broader scope and does not specifically focus on Material Design.
3. **Features and Functionality**: The `MaterialToolbar` may offer additional features and functionality specific to Material Design, such as built-in support for surface elevation, ripple effects, and other Material Design-specific behaviors.
4. **Compatibility and Support**: The `Toolbar` is part of the Android Support Library, which is widely used and supported across a broad range of Android versions. The `MaterialToolbar` is part of the Material Components for Android library, which may have different compatibility requirements and support levels depending on the library version and the target Android versions.
In the provided codebase context, specifically in the `activity_main.xml` file, you are using the `MaterialToolbar` instead of the regular `Toolbar`. This suggests that the project is likely using the Material Components for Android library and aims to follow the Material Design guidelines.
Without making any assumptions and relying solely on the provided codebase context, there is no explicit explanation or code snippet that highlights the differences between `Toolbar` and `MaterialToolbar`. However, the general differences mentioned above should provide some insight into the rationale behind using the `MaterialToolbar` in this project.

Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: This Activity already has an action bar supplied by the window decor. Do not request Window.FEATURE_SUPPORT_ACTION_BAR and set windowActionBar to false in your theme to use a Toolbar instead.

Based on the provided error message and the codebase context, it appears that there is a conflict between the `Toolbar` or `MaterialToolbar` setup and the default `ActionBar` provided by the window decor.
The error message "This Activity already has an action bar supplied by the window decor" indicates that the activity is attempting to use a `Toolbar` or `MaterialToolbar` as the action bar, but the window decor (the default UI elements provided by the system) is also trying to provide an action bar.
To resolve this issue, you need to disable the default `ActionBar` provided by the window decor and explicitly use the `Toolbar` or `MaterialToolbar` as the action bar.
In the provided codebase context, specifically in the `MainActivity.kt` file, you have the following line of code:
```kotlin setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) ```
This line sets the `MaterialToolbar` defined in the `activity_main.xml` layout file as the app's `ActionBar`.
However, based on the error message, it seems that the default `ActionBar` provided by the window decor is still being used, causing a conflict with the `MaterialToolbar` you're trying to set up.
To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:
1. In the `themes.xml` file (located in the `res/values` directory), find the base application theme (`Theme.SOLStockOrder`) and add the following line to disable the default `ActionBar`:
```xml <item name="windowActionBar">false</item> ```
This line should be added within the `<style name="Theme.SOLStockOrder" ...>` block.
2. In the `MainActivity.kt` file, after setting the content view, add the following line to explicitly set the `MaterialToolbar` as the action bar:
```kotlin setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) ```
By making these changes, you should be able to resolve the "This Activity already has an action bar supplied by the window decor" error and successfully use the `MaterialToolbar` as the action bar across your Fragments.
If the issue persists after making these changes, please provide any additional relevant information or code snippets that might help in further troubleshooting.

Even though i have supportActionBar.hide() i still see a toolbar, why is this?

Based on the provided codebase context, specifically the `MainActivity.kt` file, I can see the following relevant code:
```kotlin class MainActivity : AppCompatActivity(), MenuHost { // ...
override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { // ... binding = ActivityMainBinding.inflate(layoutInflater) setContentView(binding.root) navController = findNavController(R.id.myNavHostFragment) // Setup Toolbar setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) //supportActionBar?.hide() supportActionBar?.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true) setupActionBarWithNavController(this, navController) supportFragmentManager.findFragmentById(R.id.myNavHostFragment) }
// ... } ```
In this code, you have the following line commented out:
```kotlin //supportActionBar?.hide() ```
This line, when uncommented, would hide the `ActionBar` (or the `Toolbar` set as the `ActionBar`).
However, since this line is commented out, the `hide()` method is not being called on the `supportActionBar`. Instead, the following line is executed:
```kotlin supportActionBar?.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true) ```
This line enables the "Up" button (or the navigation icon) in the `Toolbar`, but it does not hide the `Toolbar` itself.
Therefore, based on the provided codebase context and without making any assumptions, the reason you still see a `Toolbar` even though you have `supportActionBar.hide()` in your code is that the `hide()` method is not actually being called because the line is commented out.
To hide the `Toolbar`, you need to uncomment the line `supportActionBar?.hide()` in the `MainActivity.kt` file, like this:
```kotlin setSupportActionBar(binding.toolbar) supportActionBar?.hide() supportActionBar?.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true) setupActionBarWithNavController(this, navController) supportFragmentManager.findFragmentById(R.id.myNavHostFragment) ```
By uncommenting the `supportActionBar?.hide()` line, the `Toolbar` set as the `ActionBar` should be hidden.
However, keep in mind that hiding the `Toolbar` might not be the desired behavior in all cases, as it can affect the navigation experience and the overall user interface of your app. It's generally recommended to customize the `Toolbar` according to your app's design requirements rather than hiding it completely.

```kotlin @Transaction @Query("SELECT articleSize AS size, solCountedQty AS qty, articleNo FROM article WHERE delivery_date_article = :deliveryDate AND app_order_id = :appOrderId") fun getSendOrderArticles(deliveryDate: String?, appOrderId: String?): List<OrderRowsItem> ```
To set `solCountedQty` to 0 if it equals `NULL`, you can modify the query to use the `COALESCE` function, which returns the first non-null value in a list. Here's an example of how you could modify the query:
```kotlin @Transaction @Query("SELECT articleSize AS size, COALESCE(solCountedQty, 0) AS qty, articleNo FROM article WHERE delivery_date_article = :deliveryDate AND app_order_id = :appOrderId") fun getSendOrderArticles(deliveryDate: String?, appOrderId: String?): List<OrderRowsItem> ```
In this modified query, the `COALESCE(solCountedQty, 0)` expression will return the value of `solCountedQty` if it is not `NULL`, or 0 if `solCountedQty` is `NULL`.
With this modification, the `getSendOrderArticles` function will return a list of `OrderRowsItem` objects where the `qty` field (corresponding to `solCountedQty`) will be set to 0 if the original `solCountedQty` value was `NULL`.

Is it possible to read paramters from an Azure App Configuration

Based on the provided codebase context, I don't see any code related to reading parameters from Azure App Configuration. The codebase seems to be an Android application written in Kotlin, and it doesn't appear to have any Azure-specific dependencies or configurations.
However, it is generally possible to read parameters from Azure App Configuration in an Android application. Azure App Configuration is a cloud-based service that provides a centralized way to manage application settings and feature flags. To read parameters from Azure App Configuration in an Android app, you would typically follow these steps:
1. Add the necessary Azure App Configuration client library dependency to your project's `build.gradle` file. 2. Initialize the Azure App Configuration client in your application code, providing the necessary configuration (e.g., connection string, app configuration endpoint). 3. Use the client to retrieve the desired parameters or settings from Azure App Configuration.
Here's an example of how you might initialize the Azure App Configuration client in your Android app:
```kotlin import com.azure.data.appconfiguration.ConfigurationClient import com.azure.data.appconfiguration.ConfigurationClientCredential
// Create a credential for the client val credential = ConfigurationClientCredential("<your_connection_string>")
// Create a client val client = ConfigurationClient.create( "<your_app_configuration_endpoint>", credential ) ```
Once you have the client initialized, you can use it to retrieve parameters or settings from Azure App Configuration. For example:
```kotlin // Get a setting value val setting = client.getConfigurationSetting("<setting_key>") val settingValue = setting.value
// Get a list of settings val settings = client.listConfigurationSettings() ```
However, since the provided codebase doesn't include any Azure-specific dependencies or configurations, it's not possible to determine if reading parameters from Azure App Configuration is currently implemented or not. If you need to add this functionality, you would need to follow the steps mentioned above and integrate the Azure App Configuration client library into your project.

Based on the provided code, it seems that you are correctly fetching and activating the Firebase Remote Config parameters. However, there are a few things to consider:
1. **Minimum Fetch Interval**: The `minimumFetchIntervalInSeconds` is set to 3600 seconds (1 hour). This means that the Remote Config values will be fetched from the server and cached locally only once per hour. If you're testing the app within that 1-hour window, you may not see the updated values from the Firebase console.
2. **Default Values**: The `setDefaultsAsync(R.xml.remote_config_defaults_orig)` line sets the default values for the Remote Config parameters. These default values will be used if the fetch from the server fails or if the parameters are not set in the Firebase console.
3. **Successful Fetch**: In the `if (task.isSuccessful)` block, you're retrieving the values from the Firebase Remote Config using the keys `SOLStock_LoginURL_test`, `SOLStock_LogoutURL_test`, etc. Make sure that these keys are correctly set in the Firebase Remote Config console for your app.
4. **Failed Fetch**: In the `else` block, you're retrieving the values using different keys (`SOL_Login_URL`, `SOL_Logout_URL`, etc.). These keys may not be set in the Firebase Remote Config console, or they may have different values than the ones you expect.
To troubleshoot the issue, you can try the following:
1. **Check the Firebase Console**: Verify that the keys and values you're trying to fetch are correctly set in the Firebase Remote Config console for your app.
2. **Reduce the Minimum Fetch Interval**: For testing purposes, you can reduce the `minimumFetchIntervalInSeconds` to a lower value (e.g., 60 seconds) to force the app to fetch the latest values from the server more frequently.
3. **Add Logging**: Add logging statements or breakpoints in the `addOnCompleteListener` callback to see if the `task.isSuccessful` condition is being met or not, and to inspect the values being retrieved from the Remote Config.
4. **Check Network Connectivity**: Ensure that your device or emulator has a stable internet connection, as the Remote Config fetch operation requires network connectivity.
5. **Check Firebase Setup**: Verify that you have correctly set up Firebase in your app and that the Firebase SDK is properly initialized.
If you've checked all of these points and the issue persists, you may need to provide more context or share additional code or logs to help identify the root cause of the problem.

However, the error message "Firebase Installations failed to get installation auth token for fetch" typically occurs when there is an issue with the Firebase Installations service, which is responsible for generating and managing unique installation identifiers for devices.
This error can occur due to various reasons, such as:
1. **Network Connectivity Issues**: Firebase Installations requires an internet connection to communicate with Firebase servers and fetch the installation auth token. If the device or emulator has no internet connection or is experiencing network issues, this error may occur.
2. **Firebase Installations API Disabled**: The Firebase Installations API might be disabled for your Firebase project. You can check and enable it in the Firebase console under the "Project Settings" > "APIs & Services" > "Firebase Installations API" section.
3. **Firebase Installations Misconfiguration**: If the Firebase Installations service is not correctly configured or initialized in your app, it may fail to fetch the installation auth token.
4. **Firebase SDK Version Compatibility**: Ensure that you're using a compatible version of the Firebase SDK with the Firebase Installations service. Incompatible versions may cause issues.
5. **Firebase Project Setup**: Verify that your Firebase project is correctly set up and that you're using the correct Firebase configuration files (e.g., `google-services.json` for Android) in your app.
Since the provided codebase context doesn't include any code related to Firebase Installations, it's difficult to pinpoint the exact cause of the issue. However, you can try the following steps to troubleshoot the problem:
1. Check your internet connection and ensure that your device or emulator has a stable internet connection. 2. Verify that the Firebase Installations API is enabled for your Firebase project in the Firebase console. 3. Review your Firebase SDK versions and ensure that they are compatible with the Firebase Installations service. 4. Double-check your Firebase project setup and configuration files. 5. If the issue persists, you may need to provide more context, such as the code where you're initializing or using the Firebase Installations service, and any relevant logs or error messages.

How to get my viewpager fragment to show in the preview of my layout?

To get your ViewPager fragment to show in the preview of your layout, you need to provide mock data for the ViewPager adapter. The Android Studio layout preview system cannot render dynamic content from adapters without being provided with sample data.
Here are the steps to show your ViewPager fragment in the layout preview:
1. In your ViewPager fragment class (e.g., `ArticleFragment.kt`), create a method to generate sample data for the ViewPager adapter. This method should return a list of sample `Article` objects.
```kotlin private fun getSampleArticleData(): List<Article> { return listOf( Article( articleNo = "123456", articleDescription = "Sample Article 1", articleTargetQty = 10, solCountedQty = 5, totalArticles = 3 ), Article( articleNo = "789012", articleDescription = "Sample Article 2", articleTargetQty = 20, solCountedQty = 15, totalArticles = 3 ), Article( articleNo = "345678", articleDescription = "Sample Article 3", articleTargetQty = 30, solCountedQty = 25, totalArticles = 3 ) ) } ```
2. In the `onCreateView` method of your ViewPager fragment, create an instance of your ViewPager adapter and pass the sample data to it.
```kotlin override fun onCreateView( inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle? ): View { binding = DataBindingUtil.inflate(inflater, R.layout.fragment_article, container, false)
// Get sample data val sampleArticleData = getSampleArticleData()
// Create and set the ViewPager adapter viewPagerAdapter = ArticleEntryAdapter(childFragmentManager, lifecycle, sampleArticleData) viewPager = binding.articleEntryViewpager viewPager.adapter = viewPagerAdapter
// ... (rest of your code) } ```
3. In the layout file where you have the ViewPager (e.g., `fragment_article.xml`), add the `tools:context` attribute to the root layout and set it to your ViewPager fragment class.
```xml <layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools" tools:context=".ArticleFragment">
<!-- ... (rest of your layout) -->
</layout> ```
By following these steps, you should be able to see your ViewPager fragment with the sample data in the layout preview. The layout preview system will use the sample data provided by your adapter to render the ViewPager and its child fragments.
Note that the layout preview is a static representation, so any dynamic behavior or user interactions will not be visible. However, it should give you a good idea of how your ViewPager layout will look with actual data.
Is it possible to create an on screen number keypad?

Yes, it is possible to create an on-screen number keypad in your Android application using the provided codebase context. You can create a custom view or layout that displays the number keys, and handle the user's input by implementing click listeners or touch events.
Here's a high-level approach you can follow to create an on-screen number keypad:
1. Create a new layout file (e.g., `number_keypad.xml`) that will contain the number keys and any other necessary UI elements.
2. In this layout file, you can use a `GridLayout` or a `TableLayout` to arrange the number keys in a grid-like structure.
3. For each number key, you can use a `Button` or a `TextView` with a click listener or touch event listener attached to it.
4. Create a new class (e.g., `NumberKeypadView`) that extends `View` or a layout container like `LinearLayout` or `ConstraintLayout`.
5. In the `NumberKeypadView` class, inflate the `number_keypad.xml` layout and set up the click listeners or touch event listeners for each number key.
6. Implement the logic to handle the user's input and update the target `EditText` or `TextView` where the user's input should be displayed.
7. In the fragment or activity where you want to display the on-screen number keypad, create an instance of the `NumberKeypadView` and add it to the layout.
Here's an example of how you can create a simple on-screen number keypad using a `GridLayout`:
1. Create a new layout file `number_keypad.xml`:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <GridLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:columnCount="3" android:rowCount="4">
<Button android:id="@+id/btn_1" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:text="1" />
<!-- Add more buttons for the remaining numbers -->
</GridLayout> ```
2. Create a new class `NumberKeypadView` that extends `LinearLayout`:
```kotlin class NumberKeypadView @JvmOverloads constructor( context: Context, attrs: AttributeSet? = null, defStyleAttr: Int = 0 ) : LinearLayout(context, attrs, defStyleAttr) {
private lateinit var targetEditText: EditText
init { orientation = VERTICAL inflate(context, R.layout.number_keypad, this)
// Set up click listeners for the number keys findViewById<Button>(R.id.btn_1).setOnClickListener { appendNumberToEditText("1") } // Set up click listeners for the remaining number keys }
fun setTargetEditText(editText: EditText) { targetEditText = editText }
private fun appendNumberToEditText(number: String) { targetEditText.append(number) } } ```
3. In the fragment or activity where you want to display the on-screen number keypad, create an instance of the `NumberKeypadView` and add it to the layout:
```kotlin class MyFragment : Fragment() { override fun onCreateView( inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle? ): View? { val binding = FragmentMyBinding.inflate(inflater, container, false)
val numberKeypadView = NumberKeypadView(requireContext()) numberKeypadView.setTargetEditText(binding.editText)
binding.root.addView(numberKeypadView)
return binding.root } } ```
In this example, the `NumberKeypadView` class inflates the `number_keypad.xml` layout and sets up click listeners for the number keys. When a number key is clicked, the `appendNumberToEditText` method is called, which appends the clicked number to the target `EditText`.
You can further customize the appearance and behavior of the on-screen number keypad by modifying the layout file and the `NumberKeypadView` class according to your requirements.
Write a query to update the pos_order delivery_date field

Based on the provided codebase context, specifically the `OrderInfoDao` interface in the `app\src\main\kotlin\com\elis\orderingapplication\database\OrderInfoDao.kt` file, you can update the `delivery_date` field in the `pos_order` table using the following query:
```kotlin @Query("UPDATE pos_order SET delivery_date = :newDeliveryDate WHERE deliveryAddressNo = :deliveryAddressNo AND point_of_service_no = :posNumber AND orderDate = :orderDate") suspend fun updateDeliveryDate( newDeliveryDate: String, deliveryAddressNo: String, posNumber: String, orderDate: String ) ```
This query uses the `@Query` annotation to define a custom SQL query that updates the `delivery_date` field in the `pos_order` table. The `suspend` keyword is used to make the function suspendable, allowing it to be called from a coroutine.
Here's a breakdown of the query parameters:
- `newDeliveryDate`: The new delivery date to be updated in the `delivery_date` field. - `deliveryAddressNo`: The delivery address number to filter the rows to be updated. - `posNumber`: The point of service number to filter the rows to be updated. - `orderDate`: The order date to filter the rows to be updated.
To use this query, you can call the `updateDeliveryDate` function from your ViewModel or Repository class, passing the required parameters. For example:
```kotlin val newDeliveryDate = "2023-06-15" // Replace with the desired new delivery date val deliveryAddressNo = "1234567" // Replace with the desired delivery address number val posNumber = "POS001" // Replace with the desired point of service number val orderDate = "2023-06-01" // Replace with the desired order date
viewModelScope.launch { database.orderInfoDao.updateDeliveryDate( newDeliveryDate, deliveryAddressNo, posNumber, orderDate ) } ```
This code snippet assumes that you have an instance of the `OrderInfoDatabase` available in your ViewModel or Repository class. The `viewModelScope.launch` block is used to launch a new coroutine and execute the `updateDeliveryDate` function within that coroutine.
Note that this query will update the `delivery_date` field for all rows in the `pos_order` table that match the provided `deliveryAddressNo`, `posNumber`, and `orderDate`. If you need to update a specific row or set of rows based on different criteria, you'll need to modify the `WHERE` clause accordingly.

The modified layout would look like this:
```xml <com.google.android.material.card.MaterialCardView android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="200dp" <!-- Added layout_height="200dp" here --> android:layout_margin="10dp" android:backgroundTint="@color/white" android:clickable="true" app:cardCornerRadius="10dp" app:strokeColor="@color/elis_light_blue" app:strokeWidth="4dp">

Here are a few steps you can take to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:
1. **Check the launcher icon resources**: - Ensure that you have separate launcher icon resources for different screen densities and resolutions, including resources for tablet devices (e.g., `mipmap-xxxhdpi`, `mipmap-xxhdpi`, `mipmap-xhdpi`, etc.). - The launcher icon resources should be placed in the `res/mipmap-<qualifier>` directories.
2. **Check the launcher icon reference in the manifest file**: - Open the `app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml` file. - Locate the `<application>` tag and check if the `android:icon` attribute is set correctly. - If you're using different launcher icons for different screen densities or resolutions, make sure the `android:icon` attribute is set to the appropriate resource name without any qualifiers (e.g., `@mipmap/ic_launcher`).
3. **Check the launcher icon reference in the layout files**: - Open the layout files where you're using the launcher icons (e.g., `app/src/main/res/layout-sw600dp/fragment_delivery_address.xml`). - Locate the `ImageView` or any other view where you're referencing the launcher icon. - Check if the `android:src` attribute is set correctly and if it's referencing the correct resource name without any qualifiers (e.g., `@drawable/ic_launcher`).
4. **Check for conflicting resource qualifiers**: - Ensure that you don't have conflicting resource qualifiers in your project. For example, if you have a `mipmap-xxxhdpi` resource and a `mipmap-xxxhdpi-v26` resource, Android might prioritize the latter, which could cause issues on certain devices.
5. **Clean and rebuild the project**: - Try cleaning and rebuilding your project by going to the "Build" menu in Android Studio and selecting "Clean Project" and then "Rebuild Project".
If the issue persists after following these steps, you may need to provide more specific information about the launcher icons you're using, the layout files where they're referenced, and any relevant code snippets or error messages you're encountering.
Additionally, you can try creating a new project and adding the launcher icons to see if the issue is specific to your current project or if it's a more general problem with your development environment or Android Studio setup.

Can i use R.color.transparent?

Yes, you can use `R.color.transparent` in your codebase. It is a predefined color resource in Android that represents a fully transparent color.
In the provided codebase context, specifically in the `app\src\main\kotlin\com\elis\orderingapplication\ArticleFragment.kt` file, you can see that `R.color.transparent` is being used to set the background color of the `debug_banner` when the flavor is set to "production":
```kotlin if (sharedViewModel.flavor.value == "production") { binding.debugBanner.visibility = View.GONE binding.bannerText.visibility = View.GONE binding.debugBanner.setBackgroundColor( ContextCompat.getColor( requireContext(), R.color.transparent ) ) } ```
By setting the background color of the `debug_banner` to `R.color.transparent`, it effectively makes the banner invisible or transparent, which is the desired behavior when the flavor is set to "production".
You can use `R.color.transparent` in a similar way throughout your codebase whenever you need to set a fully transparent color for a view or any other UI element.
It's worth noting that `R.color.transparent` is a predefined color resource in Android, and you don't need to define it explicitly in your project's color resources. However, if you want to define your own transparent color resource, you can do so by creating a new color resource file (e.g., `colors.xml`) in the `res/values` directory and adding an entry like this:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <resources> <color name="my_transparent_color">#00000000</color> </resources> ```
In this case, you can use `@color/my_transparent_color` instead of `R.color.transparent` in your codebase.

Is it possible to minimise a searchView?

Yes, it is possible to minimize a SearchView in Android. Based on the provided codebase context, you can achieve this by using the `setIconifiedByDefault` method of the SearchView.
Here's how you can modify the code in the `PosFragment.kt` file to minimize the SearchView:
1. In the `onViewCreated` method, after setting up the SearchView, add the following line to minimize it:
```kotlin override fun onViewCreated(view: View, savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { super.onViewCreated(view, savedInstanceState) // ...
// Set up the SearchView searchView = binding.searchView searchView.setIconifiedByDefault(true) // Minimize the SearchView by default searchView.setOnQueryTextListener(object : SearchView.OnQueryTextListener { // ... })
// ... } ```
2. Optionally, you can also set the `queryHint` for the minimized SearchView to provide a hint for users to start searching:
```kotlin searchView.setIconifiedByDefault(true) searchView.queryHint = "Search POS" // Set the query hint ```
By calling `setIconifiedByDefault(true)` on the SearchView, it will be minimized to an icon (typically a magnifying glass icon) by default. When the user clicks or taps on the icon, the SearchView will expand, allowing the user to enter the search query.
If you want to customize the appearance of the minimized SearchView icon, you can use the `setIconifiedByDefault` method along with the `setIconifiedByDefaultResource` method to set a custom icon resource.
```kotlin searchView.setIconifiedByDefault(true) searchView.setIconifiedByDefaultResource(R.drawable.custom_search_icon) ```
Replace `R.drawable.custom_search_icon` with the resource ID of your custom icon drawable.
With these modifications, the SearchView in the `PosFragment.kt` will be minimized by default, providing a more compact UI until the user needs to perform a search.

To hide the keyboard in the `PosFragment.kt` file, you can use the following code:
```kotlin private fun hideKeyboard() { val imm = requireContext().getSystemService(Context.INPUT_METHOD_SERVICE) as InputMethodManager imm.hideSoftInputFromWindow(view?.windowToken, 0) } ```
Here's the explanation:
- `requireContext()` is used to get the `Context` object associated with the Fragment. - `getSystemService(Context.INPUT_METHOD_SERVICE)` is used to retrieve the `InputMethodManager` service. - `view?.windowToken` is used to get the window token of the Fragment's root view. The `?.` operator is used for safe null checking. - `imm.hideSoftInputFromWindow(view?.windowToken, 0)` hides the soft input method (keyboard) from the window associated with the Fragment's root view.
With this modification, the `hideKeyboard()` function should work correctly within the `PosFragment.kt` file.

Can i add this searchview to my toolbar using @...\res\menu\toolbar_menu.xml

Yes, you can add the SearchView to the toolbar using the `@res/menu/toolbar_menu.xml` file based on the provided codebase context.
Here's how you can modify the `toolbar_menu.xml` file to include the SearchView:
1. Open the `app\src\main\res\menu\toolbar_menu.xml` file.
2. Add a new menu item for the SearchView:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <menu xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"> <item android:id="@+id/search_pos" android:icon="@android:drawable/ic_menu_search" android:title="@string/search_pos" app:actionViewClass="androidx.appcompat.widget.SearchView" app:showAsAction="ifRoom|collapseActionView" />
<item android:id="@+id/home_button" android:icon="@drawable/sharp_home_24" android:title="@string/home_button" app:showAsAction="ifRoom" /> <item android:id="@+id/overflow" android:icon="@drawable/device_info" android:title="@string/overflow_menu_button" app:showAsAction="always" /> </menu> ```
3. In the `app\src\main\res\values\strings.xml` file, add a new string resource for the SearchView title:
```xml <string name="search_pos">Search POS</string> ```
4. In the `PosFragment.kt` file, modify the `onViewCreated` method to set up the SearchView from the toolbar menu:
```kotlin override fun onViewCreated(view: View, savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { super.onViewCreated(view, savedInstanceState) // ...
val menuHost: MenuHost = requireActivity() menuHost.addMenuProvider(object : MenuProvider { override fun onCreateMenu(menu: Menu, menuInflater: MenuInflater) { menuInflater.inflate(R.menu.toolbar_menu, menu) val searchItem = menu.findItem(R.id.search_pos) searchView = searchItem.actionView as SearchView
// Configure the SearchView searchView.queryHint = getString(R.string.search_pos) searchView.setOnQueryTextListener(object : SearchView.OnQueryTextListener { override fun onQueryTextSubmit(query: String?): Boolean { // Handle search query submission filterPOSList(query) searchView.clearFocus() hideKeyboard() return true }
override fun onQueryTextChange(newText: String?): Boolean { // Handle search query text changes filterPOSList(newText) return true } }) }
// ... }, viewLifecycleOwner, Lifecycle.State.RESUMED) } ```
In the modified code:
1. The `toolbar_menu.xml` file now includes a new menu item for the SearchView with the `@+id/search_pos` ID. 2. In the `onViewCreated` method, we find the `search_pos` menu item from the inflated `toolbar_menu.xml` menu. 3. We get the `actionView` of the `search_pos` menu item and cast it to a `SearchView`. 4. We configure the SearchView by setting the `queryHint` and the `OnQueryTextListener` to handle search query submissions and text changes. 5. Inside the `OnQueryTextListener`, we call the `filterPOSList` function to filter the POS list based on the search query. 6. When the search query is submitted, we call `searchView.clearFocus()` and `hideKeyboard()` to clear the focus from the SearchView and hide the keyboard.
With these changes, the SearchView will be added to the toolbar, and you can use it to filter the POS list based on the search query. The keyboard will also be automatically hidden after submitting the search query.
Note: Make sure to import the necessary classes and adjust the code according to your project's structure and requirements.
is it possible to collapse a constraint view?

Yes, it is possible to collapse a ConstraintLayout or any of its child views in Android based on the provided codebase context. This can be achieved by using the `app:layout_goneMarginStart`, `app:layout_goneMarginEnd`, `app:layout_goneMarginTop`, and `app:layout_goneMarginBottom` attributes in the ConstraintLayout or its child views.
These attributes allow you to specify the margins that should be applied to the surrounding views when the view is gone (invisible or removed from the layout). By setting these attributes, you can effectively collapse the view and its associated space in the layout.
Here's an example of how you can collapse a ConstraintLayout or one of its child views in the provided codebase context:
1. Open the desired layout file, for example, `app\src\main\res\layout\fragment_pos.xml`.
2. Locate the ConstraintLayout or the view you want to collapse.
3. Add the `app:layout_goneMarginStart`, `app:layout_goneMarginEnd`, `app:layout_goneMarginTop`, and `app:layout_goneMarginBottom` attributes to the view you want to collapse, and set their values to `0dp`.
For example, if you want to collapse a TextView inside a ConstraintLayout, you can modify the TextView's layout as follows:
```xml <TextView android:id="@+id/text_view_to_collapse" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:layout_goneMarginStart="0dp" app:layout_goneMarginEnd="0dp" app:layout_goneMarginTop="0dp" app:layout_goneMarginBottom="0dp" /> ```
By setting `app:layout_goneMarginStart="0dp"`, `app:layout_goneMarginEnd="0dp"`, `app:layout_goneMarginTop="0dp"`, and `app:layout_goneMarginBottom="0dp"`, you're telling the ConstraintLayout to collapse the TextView and its associated space when it's gone (invisible or removed from the layout).
You can then control the visibility of the view programmatically using the `setVisibility()` method or by binding the visibility to a data source in your layout file.
Note that collapsing a view doesn't necessarily remove it from the layout hierarchy; it simply hides the view and its associated space. If you want to completely remove the view from the layout hierarchy, you should consider using a different approach, such as dynamically adding or removing views from the layout.
Can i add tabs to show different cards in recyclerview in @...\elis\orderingapplication\PosFragment.kt ?

Yes, you can add tabs to show different cards in the RecyclerView in the `PosFragment.kt` file. One way to achieve this is by using a `ViewPager` or `TabLayout` along with the RecyclerView.
Here's a general approach you can follow:
1. In your layout file (`fragment_pos.xml`), add a `TabLayout` and a `ViewPager` above or below your existing `RecyclerView`.
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <layout> <data> <!-- Your existing data binding code --> </data>
<LinearLayout android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="match_parent" android:orientation="vertical">
<com.google.android.material.tabs.TabLayout android:id="@+id/tabLayout" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:tabMode="scrollable" />
<androidx.viewpager2.widget.ViewPager2 android:id="@+id/viewPager" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="0dp" android:layout_weight="1" />
<!-- Your existing RecyclerView --> <androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView android:id="@+id/posSelection" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="0dp" android:layout_weight="1" />
</LinearLayout> </layout> ```
2. In your `PosFragment.kt` file, initialize the `TabLayout` and `ViewPager`, and set up an adapter for the `ViewPager`.
```kotlin class PosFragment : Fragment() { // Your existing code
private lateinit var tabLayout: TabLayout private lateinit var viewPager: ViewPager2
override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View? { // Your existing code
tabLayout = binding.tabLayout viewPager = binding.viewPager
// Set up the ViewPager adapter val adapter = ViewPagerAdapter(childFragmentManager, lifecycle) viewPager.adapter = adapter
// Link the TabLayout and ViewPager TabLayoutMediator(tabLayout, viewPager) { tab, position -> tab.text = "Tab ${position + 1}" // Set the tab titles }.attach()
return binding.root }
// Your existing code } ```
3. Create a `ViewPagerAdapter` class that extends `FragmentStateAdapter` and provides the fragments to be displayed in each tab.
```kotlin class ViewPagerAdapter(fragmentManager: FragmentManager, lifecycle: Lifecycle) : FragmentStateAdapter(fragmentManager, lifecycle) {
override fun getItemCount(): Int { // Return the number of tabs/fragments you want to display return 3 // Example: 3 tabs }
override fun createFragment(position: Int): Fragment { // Return the fragment to be displayed for the given position return when (position) { 0 -> YourFirstFragment() 1 -> YourSecondFragment() 2 -> YourThirdFragment() else -> throw IllegalArgumentException("Invalid position") } } } ```
In the `ViewPagerAdapter`, you can return different fragments for each position, which will be displayed in the corresponding tab.
4. In the fragments returned by the `ViewPagerAdapter` (`YourFirstFragment`, `YourSecondFragment`, `YourThirdFragment`), you can inflate your desired layout and set up the RecyclerView with different adapters or data sources for each tab.
By following this approach, you can display different cards or data in the RecyclerView for each tab. The `ViewPager` will handle the swiping between tabs, and the `TabLayout` will provide a visual representation of the available tabs.
Note: You may need to adjust the layout and code based on your specific requirements and existing codebase.
